sessions.title: [R]Evolution of cloud native CI/CD. From Jenkins to AI-native tools
sessions.description:
"Cloud Native is eating the world". The same happens with the domain of automation, including continuous integration tools. There are many open-source CI tools or open-source ecosystems on the market, cloud native or not: Jenkins, Argo, Woodpecker, Flux, GitLab, Dagger, Tekton, etc. There are many generations of these tools, with their architectures and use cases. We will talk about these tools and the evolution of the existing projects towards the next generation - AI-native CI tools.

What has changed in CI since cloud native became popular 10y ago? How do Open Source, CNCF, CDF impact the landscape? What's next for the tools:  cloud native dev environments, developer experience, machine learning, fuzzing and predictive testing, etc.? And what does AI bring into the next generation of tools and sustainability?

sessions.title: 50 shades of PR
sessions.description: In this short and fun talk (yes it’ll be fun!) - Avishag Sahar laments about the top blockers of PRs, but cheer up - because I’ll also provide insights into how to unblock them.

sessions.title: A Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Multi Cloud Infrastructure
sessions.description:
As cloud professionals, we face daily challenges in managing complex, multi-cloud infrastructures. Ensuring workloads across different cloud providers like GCP, AWS may feel overwhelming. We will dive into standardized reference architectures that will make your life easier by automating cross-cloud deployments & letting you focus on building and optimizing your applications.

1. Standardizing your app delivery pipeline using github and reducing friction from development to production.

2. Automating Infrastructure with Terraform(IaC) for consistent deployments across multiple cloud providers.

3. Achieving High Availability with Cross-Cloud Connectivity with workloads running in AWS and GCP

4. Explore services like databases and Kubernetes clusters on GCP interacting with VM's in AWS through automated infrastructure.

You’ll leave with practical tools, reference architectures and insights that will bring efficiency, reliability, and peace of mind to your multi-cloud deployments.

sessions.title: A server for every user: Build serverless apps with Durable Objects
sessions.description:
Serverless architectures offer scalability and cost benefits, but managing application state remains challenging. What if you could spin up a tiny server for every user with the same cost and scalability benefits? A server for every user, in a serverless architecture sounds new, right?
In this talk, I’ll introduce you to Durable Objects and help you understand the new paradigm of building stateful serverless apps. You will learn about the various benefits like low latency, faster database operations, and handling states for your serverless app.

sessions.title: Accelerate Your Development and CI/CD Pipelines with Dagger
sessions.description:
Tired of environment drift and inconsistent build results across machines and CI servers? Frustrated by onboarding delays when setting up development environments on new hardware or debugging why scripts fail in CI but work locally?

If any of the above resonates, this workshop (and Dagger) is for you.

Dagger is a portable, programmable CI/CD engine that runs your pipelines in containers. 

In this workshop, we'll explore how Dagger can:

Eliminate Environment Discrepancies: Use containerization to ensure your development and CI environments are identical.

Simplify Onboarding: Create self-contained environments that new team members can spin up instantly.

Streamline CI/CD Pipelines: Define complex pipelines with code-first configuration, reducing failures due to environment differences.

Enhance Productivity: Focus on coding rather than environment setup and debugging.


Through a hands-on session, we'll port an existing development and CI setup to Dagger using a realistic example project. You'll gain practical experience in:

Writing Dagger pipelines using Go

Orchestrating builds, tests, and deployments in a consistent environment

Integrating Dagger into existing workflows


By the end of this workshop, you'll be equipped to leverage Dagger to standardize environments, accelerate your CI/CD pipelines, and improve team collaboration.

sessions.title: Advancing AI and ML in the Cloud: Unlocking Innovation with Scalable Intelligence
sessions.description:
AI and ML are transforming industries by enabling faster insights, intelligent automation, and data-driven decision-making. This session will dive into the latest advancements in AI and ML in the cloud, focusing on large language models (LLMs), intelligent search, document processing, and automated model fine-tuning. Attendees will gain a deep understanding of how to build and deploy scalable AI solutions while maintaining security, governance, and cost efficiency.  

Through a live demo and hands-on tutorial, participants will learn how to implement AI-driven workflows, optimize machine learning models, and integrate intelligent automation into their data pipelines. Whether you're a data engineer, analyst, or AI practitioner, this session will equip you with practical strategies and best practices to accelerate your AI and ML adoption in the cloud.

sessions.title: AI Compass: A Case Study From Strategy To Adoption
sessions.description: This talk showcases a real case study from a customer operating in a highly regulated industry. The case provides a high-level end-to-end overview how Generative AI (GenAI) was strategically deployed to eliminate legal review process for online content. Due to restrictions in advertising activities - the customer was legally forbidden from marketing on social media and other online channels, except their website - the customer sought a strategy to author content that not only appealed to their target audience, but also was brand and legally compliant. By deploying Large Language Models (LLM) in a Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) architecture, supported by workflow, content-authoring front-end and CMS integration tools, the solution shortened the editorial process from 2-3 months to 4-6 weeks.

sessions.title: AI-Native: The Next Revolution after Cloud Native
sessions.description: Cloud-native has redefined our approach to building and scaling software—from containers to microservices. Today, AI is about to trigger an even more radical transformation. This revolution goes beyond new technologies; it calls for a complete rethinking of our software, architectural design, and even organizational collaboration. Although the AI-native horizon is still forming, the promise of groundbreaking change is undeniable. Join me as I explore new challenges as well as endless possibilities.

sessions.title: Animated guide to Kubernetes scheduling
sessions.description: Deep dive into Kubernetes scheduling, focused on kube-scheduler and default plugins that it uses. Slides include scheduling-flow animations for clarity.

sessions.title: Architecting and Building a K8s-based AI Platform
sessions.description:
Developing a scalable and production-ready AI platform poses significant challenges for organisations. Beyond a modular and flexible architecture, critical aspects such as infrastructure automation, orchestration, model deployment, and lifecycle management must be efficiently addressed. Kubernetes and open-source technologies provide a powerful foundation for tackling these challenges.

In this talk, we will explore the conceptual architecture and blueprint of a cloud-native AI platform, outlining the key design principles and best practices that enable scalability, automation, and reproducibility. We will then demonstrate how to build this platform step by step - both locally and in the public cloud - leveraging Kubernetes, open-source tools, and GitOps. The focus will be on creating a highly automated, repeatable, and production-ready environment for machine learning and AI workloads.

sessions.title: Architecting Resilient Apps in Cloud
sessions.description:
This talk introduces some patterns and practices for creating apps that are resilient and scalable, two essential goals of many modern architecture exercises. A well-designed app scales up and down as demand increases and decreases, and is resilient enough to withstand service disruptions.

A resilient app is one that continues to function despite failures of system components. Resilience requires planning at all levels of your architecture. It influences how you lay out your infrastructure and network and how you design your app and data storage. Resilience also extends to people and culture.

Building and operating resilient apps is hard. This is especially true for distributed apps, which might contain multiple layers of infrastructure, networks, and services. Mistakes and outages happen, and improving the resilience of your app is an ongoing journey. With careful planning, you can improve the ability of your app to withstand failures. With proper processes and organizational culture, you can also learn from failures to further increase your app's resilience.

Testing resiliency for an application is equally important and key to success.

I will be talking on best practices for building resilient Cloud apps through my experience and also how you can test resiliency using Chaos Engineering.

High level Agenda

1) Embracing Failure at Scale
2) Avoiding Cascading Failures
3) Preventing Service Failure with Health Check
4) Caching for resiliency
5) Chaos Engineering Experiments

sessions.title: Architecting Secure and Resilient Serverless Microservices for RESTful APIs on AWS
sessions.description:
This presentation addresses the growing need for security in serverless microservice architectures, particularly in the context of RESTful APIs. As organizations increasingly adopt serverless computing for its scalability and flexibility, securing these architectures becomes a critical priority. The session will explore strategies for building highly secure and resilient serverless systems, with an emphasis on comprehensive security measures from the network perimeter all the way through the application layer.

A key area of focus will be perimeter security, highlighting how to protect serverless environments from external threats and unauthorized access. We will discuss how to implement robust network boundaries, secure traffic flows, and protect against common attack vectors spanning from Layer 3 (network layer) through to Layer 7 (application layer). This includes techniques for defending against DDoS attacks, network-based threats, and more advanced application-level attacks such as SQL injection, cross-site scripting, and other vulnerabilities that can compromise the integrity of RESTful APIs.

In addition to perimeter security, the talk will cover best practices for ensuring high availability and fault tolerance in serverless systems. We will address how to design microservice architectures that are resilient to both external and internal failures, ensuring business continuity even in the face of unexpected events. Automation of security monitoring, threat detection, and incident response will also be discussed, empowering attendees to build proactive defenses and rapidly respond to emerging threats.

Targeted at DevOps professionals, security engineers, and cloud architects, this session aims to provide actionable insights into securing serverless applications in the modern cloud landscape. Attendees will leave with a deeper understanding of how to architect resilient, secure serverless microservices, protecting APIs at every layer—from the network perimeter to the application interface—ensuring both security and operational resilience.

sessions.title: Are you compliant?
sessions.description: This talk will describe the essential concepts of compliance frameworks and policies, specifically in the context of cloud-native infrastructure. Attendees will gain a comprehensive understanding of what compliance means, the role of various frameworks, and the importance of well-defined policies in maintaining regulatory and operational standards. The session will cover the fundamentals of compliance frameworks, provide examples of widely adopted standards, and delve into the technical controls that underpin these frameworks. Additionally, the presentation will include a live demonstration on how to evaluate compliance within cloud-native environments and highlight common challenges that organizations face in achieving and maintaining compliance.

sessions.title: Automate the Automation with Terraform
sessions.description:
We spend hours automating infrastructure with Terraform—so why rely on ClickOps to set up the automation itself? It’s time to take automation to the next level.

This talk provides a deep dive into the architecture of a fully automated system where Terraform orchestrates not just infrastructure, but the entire automation stack. Using a new and innovative class of Terraform module—the AT-AT (Automate the Automation with Terraform)—we’ll explore how to:

✅ Automate Azure infrastructure necessary for automation platform
✅ Automate GitHub repositories and enforce best practices
✅ Configure GitHub Actions pipelines dynamically with Terraform

No matter what your cloud of choice might be, or whether you use GitHub Actions, Azure DevOps or something else, this session will show you how to eliminate human toil and build a self-sustaining automation engine—just by using the power of Terraform to "Automate the Automation".

Join us and let’s end ClickOps once and for all!

sessions.title: AWS Right-Sizing: Fine-Tune Your Migration for Peak Performance
sessions.description:
Many AWS migrations fail to deliver the expected improvements in cost and performance. Even the simplest migration approach (re-hosting) should bring positive results when done correctly.

In this session, we’ll explore the key factors that directly impact AWS cost and performance, helping you understand how to fine-tune your cloud environment for maximum efficiency. We’ll discuss common pitfalls, right-sizing strategies, and how to break free from the default choices (like general-purpose instances and volumes) when specialized workloads demand more tailored solutions.

If you're planning a migration or looking to optimize an existing AWS environment, you need this session to be equipped with the insights and tools to make AWS work for you.

sessions.title: Become a 10x Developer with Go Performance Optmization
sessions.description:
Performance optimization makes you a 10x software engineer. You can help your company save money or serve more customers with the same resources. It is a mandatory skill on the resume if you want to stand out from the crowd. By optimizing performance, you also gain a deeper understanding of how the Go runtime works under the hood, making you more performance-oriented when writing Go code.

This session shows you how to optimize your Go code from a CPU and memory perspective.

Unfortunately, performance optimization is not a trivial or straightforward process. Whenever a software engineer wants to optimize code, he often stumbles across several terms such as profiling, tracing, latency, throughput, Garbage Collector, heap, stack, etc. These terms can easily create confusion and headaches.

If you've ever experienced this pain or want to avoid it in the future, this session comes to the rescue.

We start with their definitions and usages so we all speak the same language throughout the session.

Then, we explore the performance optimization process. It's an iterative process involving studying, benchmarking, changing code, benchmarking (again), comparing, and deciding. Thanks to this session, you'll learn to go through this process without getting lost.

You'll understand that performance optimization is not just about changing source code. It's a journey. And before embarking on it, you need everything ready and set.

We'll also cover the importance of understanding collected metrics and values and how to use them to evaluate potential code changes. I will show you how to capture a snapshot of your program's state and analyze it effectively.

Then, we explore the tools Go provides for performance analysis. Go has an excellent tooling system to support you in this journey.

Some topics covered are benchmarks, Go compiler's flags, Go Garbage Collection, escape analysis, inlining, core dumps, memory and CPU profiles, trace, pprof, stress-test tools, Go's environment variables, etc.

By learning a bit about each topic, you can try to optimize your code with the right tool. Furthermore, you'll understand which tools are worth studying for your specific scenario.

Whether you're a newbie on the subject or have previous experience with performance optimization, this session will provide you with several hints, concepts, and uh-oh moments.

Remember: software efficiency is as important as software correctness.

sessions.title: Beyond Microservices: Running VMs, WASM, and AI Workloads on Kubernetes
sessions.description:
Kubernetes has evolved far beyond its roots as an orchestration platform. Today, it's a powerful and flexible engine capable of managing a wide variety of workloads, from virtual machines to WebAssembly applications to AI inference models. In this talk, we'll explore how Kubernetes can be leveraged to run non-traditional workloads, tackling common challenges and showcasing cutting-edge solutions.
We'll start by discussing KubeVirt, a technology that enables seamless migration of on-premise VMs into a Kubernetes environment, making it easier to consolidate infrastructure and modernize legacy systems. Next, we’ll dive into WebAssembly (WASM) workloads using SpinKube, highlighting WASM’s security, sandboxing, and near-instant startup times that make it ideal for lightweight cloud-native applications. Lastly, we’ll cover running AI models and inferences on Kubernetes with an emphasis on optimizing performance through proper cluster topology, hardware considerations like GPUs, and scalable configurations.
Throughout the talk, I will showcase live demos of each workload type—VMs, WASM apps, and AI models—running on Kubernetes, providing practical examples and real-world use cases. Whether you're looking to expand Kubernetes usage in your projects or exploring new workloads to orchestrate, this session will offer valuable insights and hands-on solutions for diverse compute needs.

sessions.title: Beyond the Dockerfile: Taking Your Containers to Azure
sessions.description:
Let's face it: too many talks stop at the Dockerfile and leave you wondering how to actually get your containers live.

In this session, Florian Lenz take you on a practical journey from local development to fully automated, cloud-powered deployments on Azure. You'll learn how to set up CI/CD pipelines that seamlessly build and push your containers, choose the best Azure service—whether that's Kubernetes, Container Instances, or App Services—and automate your deployments with infrastructure-as-code. 

We'll also roll up our sleeves and tackle real-world challenges, ensuring your containerized apps are production-ready. If you're already comfortable with Docker and eager to scale up to Azure, join Florian for a session for plenty of actionable tips.

sessions.title: Boosting Developer Productivity with Ephemeral Testing Environments
sessions.description:
As modern architecture stacks are becoming more complex, replicating the production environment on developers' devices becomes increasingly challenging. Some organizations provide dedicated “development” and, in some cases, ”staging” environments. However, as teams expand, these shared environments turn into bottlenecks, slowing down the continuous delivery of software value.

During this session, we will explore how Kubernetes enables the creation of unlimited Ephemeral Testing Environments, providing on-demand production replicas for comprehensive testing. We will then discuss the steps we took to enable this transition: how we restructured our software development lifecycle, the strategies we implemented to control costs, the impact on developer productivity, and finally, the lessons learned from our mistakes along the way.

sessions.title: Breaking Barriers: My Journey from Robotics to Cloud Native at 14
sessions.description:
At by just the age of 14, I have achieved a lot of things by following my passion. For as far as I can remember, I have been attracted to cool technology. I started robotics when I was 8 because it was cool tech. I learned python and built games at 10 because I found that to be a cool tech. I transitioned to building my own homelab with a 10-year-old barely usable laptop I found in my closet because microservices and containerization were cool at the time. I pursued many of the AWS certifications including the AWS DevOps Professional because I found that cool at the time.

In this talk, I will share the secrets of what I did to achieve this much at such a young age and will also provide the readers with a roadmap to apply similar principles in their lives.

sessions.title: Breaking Boundaries: DevSecOps and the Radical Shift-Left Movement
sessions.description: This workshop will explore the transformative approach of integrating security into the DevOps pipeline early in the development lifecycle, commonly known as "shifting left". Attendees will gain practical skills and knowledge to enhance the security of their CI/CD pipelines, ensuring a more robust and secure development process. The workshop will include a mix of theoretical insights, hands-on labs, interactive sessions, and group exercises, focusing on open-source tools and best practices.

sessions.title: Breaking Free: Kubernetes Unleashed for Small Teams
sessions.description:
In today's fast-paced development environment, small teams often face the challenge of managing and scaling their applications efficiently. This talk will explore how Kubernetes, a powerful container orchestration platform, can be a game-changer for small teams. We will discuss the reasons why small teams should consider adopting Kubernetes, including its ability to streamline deployment processes, enhance scalability, and improve resource utilization.

Through a straightforward example that is easy to understand, attendees will discover how to get started with Kubernetes in a way that minimizes effort and complexity. The session will showcase a practical approach to setting up a basic Kubernetes cluster and deploying an initial application. By the end of the talk, participants will be inspired and equipped with the knowledge to begin their Kubernetes journey, understanding the significant benefits it can bring to their team's productivity and efficiency.

sessions.title: Bringing Cloud-Native Agility to Bare-Metal Kubernetes with Cluster API and Metal³
sessions.description:
When we think of Cloud Native, we often think of public cloud—but on-premises infrastructure remains a critical part of the equation. Running Kubernetes on-prem is already more complex than in a managed cloud environment, but deploying clusters directly on bare metal—without hypervisors or private cloud layers—introduces an additional layer of operational challenges.

In this session, we'll dive deep into how Cluster API (CAPI) and Metal³ transform bare-metal Kubernetes deployments by bringing software-defined infrastructure principles to physical hardware. We'll cover:

-Automated provisioning of bare-metal nodes using Kubernetes-native APIs
-Cluster API's declarative approach to scaling Kubernetes across physical servers
-Metal³'s integration with Ironic to enable hardware lifecycle management
-Real-world use cases and the challenges of bare-metal operations at scale

Join us to explore how these open-source tools are bringing cloud-like automation to bare metal.

sessions.title: Build Cloud-Native Microservices with Dapr
sessions.description:
Microservices architectures offer scalability, flexibility and modularity, but they also introduce new complexities for developers. From managing service-to-service communication and state persistence to implementing security, reliability and monitoring, developing microservices often means reinventing the wheel for each service. Add to that the challenges of local development, debugging and building efficient microservices can feel overwhelming.

In this session, we'll take a deep dive into the common struggles developers face when building microservices and how Dapr (Distributed Application Runtime) can streamline this process. Dapr abstracts the complexity of infrastructure issues by providing reusable building blocks for service invocation, state management, pub/sub messaging and more, allowing you to focus on your core business logic.

By the end of the session, you'll see how Dapr can dramatically reduce the repetitive development tasks associated with building microservices. You'll see a live demonstration of a cloud-native order processing system where Dapr seamlessly addresses common microservice challenges within Azure Container Apps.

sessions.title: Building a Flexible Data Warehouse in E-commerce Without Database
sessions.description:
In modern e-commerce, success starts in the shopping cart, but what ends up there depends on data. Data is a key element in e-commerce. It allows us to analyze customer behavior, optimize processes and offerings, and ultimately increase sales. However, a traditional data warehouse comes with costs and limited flexibility. So, is it possible to perform scalable and efficient analyses without it?
During this talk, I will demonstrate how to leverage the power of the public cloud to build a modern, serverless data warehouse. Through practical e-commerce examples, we will explore how to conduct data analysis—without the need to build a traditional data warehouse.

sessions.title: Building a Kubernetes Distribution From Scratch: Lessons From an Official Distribution Journey
sessions.description:
What does it take to build a Kubernetes distribution from the ground up? In this session, we'll explore the journey of creating Canonical's Kubernetes distribution, diving into the technical challenges, strategic decisions, and key lessons learned—insights that apply to any distribution or open-source project.

We'll break down the fundamentals: What exactly is a Kubernetes distribution? How do they differ, and what do they entail? From managing cluster state to release automation and documentation, we'll cover the critical components that shape a production-ready distribution.

By the end of this talk, you'll have a clear understanding of what goes into building and maintaining a Kubernetes distribution, along with the essential factors that set one apart from another.

sessions.title: Building a Lightning Fast Firewall with Java & eBPF
sessions.description:
eBPF is buzzing all over the cloud native world, as the cutting-edge technology reshaping the way we understand performance, security, and observability within kernel space. Java, with its recent strides in modernization and optimization, from enhancing startup times to facilitating native execution and advancing machine learning applications, stands at the cusp of this transformative era.

Join us in this journey, where we will embark on an ambitious challenge to write and build a high-throughput firewall leveraging the combined power of eBPF and Java. We'll start with a deep dive into eBPF's capabilities for kernel-level packet manipulation, then transition to how Java's latest advancements, particularly through Project Panama, enable seamless native code invocation and interoperability. Our focus will then converge to a hands-on demonstration of building a simple firewall using eBPF and Java, integrating kernel-level operations with high-level programming for real-time performance enhancements. 

Attendees will gain practical insights into deploying eBPF programs from Java using the hello-ebpf library, managing packet flows efficiently, and implementing firewall rules with precision, leveraging the strengths of both worlds.

sessions.title: Building AI-Native Platforms: Foundations for the Next Generation of Intelligent Applications
sessions.description: The convergence of AI and cloud-native technologies is giving rise to a new breed of platforms: AI-native platforms. These platforms are designed from the ground up to support the unique demands of AI workloads, enabling organizations to build, deploy, and scale intelligent applications with unprecedented speed and efficiency. This talk explores the key characteristics of AI-native platforms, delving into their architecture, capabilities, and the benefits they offer. We'll discuss how these platforms address the challenges of data management, compute orchestration, model training and deployment, and MLOps, providing a foundation for the next generation of AI-powered innovation.

sessions.title: Building Infrastructure Tools with Kubernetes Operators and Go
sessions.description:
In this hands-on workshop, participants will learn how to build powerful infrastructure management tools using Kubernetes (K8s) Operators written in Go. Kubernetes Operators extend the functionality of Kubernetes by automating complex, domain-specific tasks, and managing custom resources at scale. Through this workshop, attendees will gain a deep understanding of the Operator pattern, best practices in Operator development, and how Go can be used to create robust, production-grade Operators.

Key topics covered will include:
- Introduction to Kubernetes Operators: What they are, why they're needed, and how they fit into the Kubernetes ecosystem.
- Deep dive into the Operator Framework: Building, testing, and deploying Operators with Go.
- Custom Resource Definitions (CRDs) and how to manage lifecycle events of custom resources.
- Best practices for error handling, reconciliation loops, and scalability in Operator development.
- Hands-on labs: Writing a simple Operator in Go to manage real-world infrastructure resources.
- Advanced Operator patterns, including status management, handling upgrades, and building for high availability.

sessions.title: Building operators using micro-controller architectures
sessions.description: Operators are essential for automating cloud-native application management, but monolithic architectures hinder scalability and maintenance. In this session, we explore the evolution of operators, detailing our six-year journey from monolithic to modular design with the launch of our open-source MongoDB Controllers for Kubernetes (MCK). We'll examine monolithic operators using examples like the Prometheus operator and the MongoDB Community operator. Then we'll explore modular design approaches in projects like AWS Controllers for Kubernetes (ACK) and Crossplane, which decompose the monolith into separate controllers to achieve greater modularity, scalability, and simplified maintenance. We’ll dive deeper giving technical insights into the challenges we faced and the solutions we implemented, including architectural considerations between monolithic and modular designs, strategies for code reuse without tight coupling, and adaptations to build and deployment processes.

sessions.title: Build-Measure-Learn for Platform Engineering: Applying Lean Startup Principles to Platforms
sessions.description:
How can we build outstanding platforms that truly meet our developers' needs? The answer is through real-world learning, early and often. Yet, we often base design choices of our platforms primarily on intuition, preference, and conviction, which can differ greatly from what our users — developers — actually need. This leads to increased cognitive load and platforms that don't facilitate or accelerate their work as intended. In Platform Engineering, this is a significant challenge.

Drawing from years of experience and battle-tested approaches, this talk provides actionable strategies to overcome this issue by adopting a lean startup-inspired methodology. Attendees will learn how to incorporate a lightweight build-measure-learn cycle into platform product management, enabling you to repeatedly build truly user-centric platforms, regardless of the specific domain. We will explore turning intuitions into testable hypotheses, validating them, and co-creating the platform with the user.

sessions.title: Cilium and eBPF: The Ultimate Duo for Kubernetes Network Security
sessions.description:
Cilium, powered by eBPF, is revolutionizing Kubernetes network security and observability. In this session, we’ll explore how eBPF (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) enables high-performance, programmable networking within the Linux kernel, allowing Cilium to deliver unparalleled control and visibility for containerized environments. 
Discover how Cilium enforces fine-grained network policies, facilitates service mesh capabilities, and detects threats in real time without the complexity of traditional sidecar-based approaches. We'll discuss practical use cases, including traffic filtering, encryption, and runtime security, along with a live demonstration of securing Kubernetes clusters with Cilium. Join us to learn why Cilium and eBPF are becoming the cornerstone of modern cloud-native security strategies.

sessions.title: CNCF sandbox project k8up under the hood
sessions.description: Join Aarno for an exclusive under-the-hood exploration of k8up, a CNCF Sandbox project simplifying Kubernetes backups and recovery. Through a technical live demo, discover how k8up seamlessly integrates with Kubernetes clusters, safeguarding critical data assets and automating backups effortlessly. Leveraging the Restic tool for storage, k8up ensures operational excellence in Cloud-native environments. Don't miss this opportunity to unravel the secrets of Kubernetes data resilience with k8up.

sessions.title: Cognitive and Self-Adaptive System for Effective Distributed-Tracing (using Jaeger, Open Tracing)
sessions.description: In distributed systems and microservices, dynamic API tracing is essential for diagnosing failures and performance bottlenecks. However, existing implementations typically sample only 1-5% of traces due to storage and scalability constraints, leading to a biased representation that favors normal execution flows. This skew impedes effective troubleshooting. Our solution leverages Machine Learning and Cognitive techniques to dynamically adjust the sampling rate based on real-time system behavior, prioritizing high-value traces related to failures or anomalies. This adaptive approach has significantly reduced Mean Time to Resolve (MTTR) for SRE teams by improving root cause identification. The Adaptive Sampling algorithm, driven by data analysis, ensures balanced trace distribution, reduces storage overhead, optimizes resource utilization, and enhances trace metric analysis, offering a scalable solution to challenges in observability and system performance management.

sessions.title: Composable Platforms: Modular Platform Engineering with Kratix and Backstage
sessions.description:
Constructing and managing platforms for diverse teams and workloads presents a significant challenge in today's cloud-native environment. This session introduces the concept of composable platforms, using modular, reusable components as the foundation for platform engineering. This talk will demonstrate how using Kratix, a workload-centric framework, and Backstage an extensible developer portal enables the creation of self-service platforms that balance standardization with adaptability.  

The session will detail platform design for developer workflows through Backstage, and using Kratix Promises for varied workload requirements. Attendees will gain practical insights into building scalable and maintainable platforms through real-world examples, architectural patterns, and a live demonstration of a fully integrated Kratix-Backstage deployment.

sessions.title: Concurrency Testing using Custom Linux Schedulers
sessions.description:
Consider a concurrency bug in your service that occurs once in a million machine hours of production runtime. How do you go about debugging it? And what if the interactions with the rest of the system—not just your application—are responsible?

With the new scheduler extensions in the Linux kernel, we can write custom schedulers in eBPF to help tackle this problem. We demonstrate a scheduler designed to make concurrency bugs more likely, increasing their frequency so you can focus profiling and debugging on fewer machines in a shorter timeframe.

In this talk, we show how to implement your own scheduler, how our approach enables whole-machine concurrency testing, and share some of the bugs we’ve found and fixed using this technique.

sessions.title: Containing the Threat: Analyzing cryptomining campaigns
sessions.description:
Container technologies have revolutionized application deployment and scalability, but they've also introduced new attack surfaces for threat actors. This presentation delves into the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) employed by some of the notorious cybercrime groups, such as TeamTNT, in exploiting container vulnerabilities.
We'll begin with an overview of container security fundamentals and common misconfigurations. We'll demonstrate how TeamTNT has evolved their tactics over time, adapting to improved security measures and expanding their target scope. Attendees will gain insights into:
TeamTNT's malware and C2 infrastructure
Best practices for hardening container environments against similar attacks
The importance of runtime security and continuous monitoring in containerized environments
This talk is aimed at security practitioners, DevOps engineers, and IT professionals looking to deepen their understanding of real-world container security threats and mitigation strategies.
The presentation will provide actionable recommendations for security professionals to enhance their container security posture and stay ahead of emerging threats in this domain.

sessions.title: Continuous API Mocking and Testing with Microcks, Keptn, and Testkube
sessions.description:
In dynamic API development, efficiency and reliability are critical. This talk introduces three powerful cloud-native frameworks: Microcks, Keptn and Testkube. 

Microcks enables automated API mocking and testing in a Kubernetes-native environment, supporting various API standards such as REST, gRPC, and GraphQL. Keptn provides event-driven orchestration for testing and QA, ensuring smooth API deployments. Testkube provides a flexible test execution environment for Kubernetes, allowing API tests to be triggered based on events. We will demonstrate how these tools accelerate API development, increase cloud-native software delivery agility, and ensure robust, standards-compliant, and well-tested APIs.

sessions.title: Convergence on Platforms
sessions.description: As organisations grow, they need to be more nimble which leads to a desire to simplify, whether for developers or business. We typically see organisations stumble through accelerating development, implementing DevOps before pivoting to SRE. They copy what other organisations have done by implementing a Cloud Center of Excellence or adopting other models for merging development and operating functions. Eventually as the challenges around "You build it, you run it" become clearer a platform emerges. But how do these chaotic transformations lead to this convergence? Whether your platform serves developers or customers the foundational concepts heavily align. In this talk we'll look at the ways platforms emerge and the key considerations necessary for one to succeed. As we go through time to understand how convergence happens we will examine carcinisation and what elements of it can help us understand how organisations converge on a similar approach.

sessions.title: Convey your legacy to the cloud with the Konveyor project
sessions.description:
Are you looking to update or move your application to the cloud? Or maybe you just want to see how much work is involved? Or do you want to move it automatically after analysing it?

Updating applications used to take a long time and can be very unpredictable, but now there are lots of tools that can automate lots of the modernisation process. One of these is the the Konveyor project, which is a sandbox project in the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF). Konveyor analyses your application for various patterns that hinder successful further development and operation in the cloud. A comprehensive report shows the problem areas, as well as the expected costs and suggested solutions.Based on the analysis, Konveyor integrates OpenRewrite, an automation tool for migration. For many findings, there are so-called recipes (small scripts) that adapt the code, dependencies or build steps.

In this talk, I will show how the described tools can help to move a sample application into the cloud and you will learn how you can use the tools in your own migrations.

sessions.title: CSI Observability: Finding Bad Coding Patters in Traces and Logs
sessions.description:
Excessive logging, duplicated logs per request, logs without trace context, traces with too many calls to depending services, N+1 Call Patterns, .... The list of bad coding patterns is long.
In this session you learn how to do "forensics on OpenTelemetry Traces and Logs" to detect the top problem patterns that would lead to bad performance, scalability and high costs in production environments.
You will learn how to make this data available to your engineers so they can learn and start crafting code that adheres to logging and coding standards by integrating those checks into your CI/CD. See it as a way to enforce good coding and logging practices!

sessions.title: CSI Snapshots and Clones for Performance-critical Applications in Kubernetes
sessions.description: Abstract: Efficient data management is critical for modern applications, and Kubernetes' Container Storage Interface (CSI) has transformed persistent storage operations. This session explores the advanced capabilities of CSI, focusing on snapshots and clones to optimize workflows, enhance performance, and simplify processes. Through real-world examples, discover how snapshots enable disaster recovery and clones support rapid development and testing. Gain insights into CSI’s architecture, practical implementation, and best practices with SimplyBlock CSI. A live demo will showcase setup, usage, and data lifecycle management. We’ll also address performance trade-offs in large-scale environments and resource optimization strategies. Finally, explore the future of CSI with ongoing enhancements and ways the Kubernetes community can drive storage innovation.

sessions.title: Databases on Kubernetes: Playing with Fire or the Future of the Cloud?
sessions.description:
Running Databases on Kubernetes is often considered risky and complex – but does it have to be?

In this session, we will demonstrate how to efficiently and securely manage databases in Kubernetes environments using CNPG (CloudNativePG). We will explore best practices for deployment and maintenance, address common challenges, and highlight the advantages CNPG offers—from scalability to simplified management. Discover why running databases on Kubernetes is not only feasible but a promising future for the cloud.

sessions.title: Deploying applications to Kubernetes using Helm
sessions.description:
Helm is a package manager for Kubernetes which simplifies deployments to Kubernetes.

With Helm, applications are bundled into Charts which makes it easy to build, install, upgrade, and share complex Kubernetes applications.

In this session we'll go over exactly what Helm is, the benefits it brings, and how to deploy applications to Kubernetes.

Then we'll look at upgrading applications using Helm and then rolling back to a previous version. 

To finish the session we'll then look at creating our own Helm Charts and storing them in a Chart Repository.

This session is for anyone who has worked with Kubernetes and want to learn about Helm. Each topic covered in this session will be accompanied with live demos.

sessions.title: DevOps done right: RBAC
sessions.description:
Daniel will provide insights and practical approaches to role-based access control.. as lighthearted and entertaining as such topic can be.

In today’s fast-paced IT environments, ensuring the right people have the right access to the right resources is critical. Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) is a powerful tool that helps streamline access management, reduce security risks, and maintain compliance. But how do you implement RBAC effectively across different stages and systems in your environment?

Join me for an informative and fun session where we’ll demystify RBAC and provide you with a clear understanding of its core principles. We’ll cover essential terminology, explore the key concepts, and discuss how to apply RBAC consistently across various stages of your environment. Additionally, you’ll learn about best practices to ensure your RBAC implementation is robust, scalable, and adaptable to your organization’s needs.

sessions.title: DevSecOps Guide to Bulletproof Your Development Workflow
sessions.description:
In today's fast-paced software development landscape, security can no longer be sacrificed; it's a fundamental requirement. 

As you get ready for this talk, your challenges might be messy or inexistent security process, determining critical software components to safeguard, how to seamlessly integrate different scans in your development workflow, and how to build a DevSecOps culture.

By the end of "DevSecOps Guide to Bulletproof Your Development Workflow", you'll be ready to take these challenges head-on and have a clear understanding of how to strengthen your development workflow with DevSecOps practices. 

Join me as we learn how we can build a better, more bulletproof workflow that meets the demands of the users while providing fast delivery, quality software and maintain the highest security standards.

sessions.title: Docker vs Podman
sessions.description: Both solutions are great for single host container handling. But what are the differences, pros and cons? In this talk we will take a closet look into these topics and give some recommendations which one may be better in which situation.

sessions.title: Don't Over-engineer your Observability stack Period
sessions.description:
Our observability stack looked like a teenager's gaming PC setup - RGB everywhere. We had 8 monitoring tools burning $10K monthly, multiple dashboards showing the same metrics differently, teams debating which tool to trust, and alerts that everyone ignored.

Join the session as Prerit walks us around how they removed chaos from their observability track by consolidating to 3 core tools & five golden signals, cut costs by 72%, and improved MTTR from 2 hours to 15 minutes. We will also explore:

● Why 90% of your tools are probably redundant and how they identified them.
● Building effective observability with minimal tooling
● Picking up the core metrics that actually matter

sessions.title: Double the Efficiency: Kubernetes Autoscaling with Karpenter and KEDA
sessions.description: Autoscaling in Kubernetes can be significantly simpler when you have the right tools to help you. Who doesn’t want a highly efficient Kubernetes cluster? You, me, and even our planet. The novel approach of Karpenter for node autoscaling helps many organisations reduce their spending by up to 70% on their cloud infrastructure. KEDA as an established standard for pod scaling plays an equally important role in the autoscaling ecosystem. How can these two technologies work together for even greater efficiency? This session offers practical insights from KEDA and Karpenter contributors into the current state of autoscaling, and it will give you a set of useful recommendations you can apply after leaving the conference.

sessions.title: Effortless, standardised homelab observability with eBPF
sessions.description:
Running a homelab means running a diverse set of applications like NextCloud, readeck.org, usememos.com.

They are written in many languages and frameworks and in general lack a good way to monitor them. The old way to monitor them involved having a basic blackbox_exporter enabled synthetic monitoring. Even instrumented, each application has a different set of metrics, leading to complex alerting and dashboards.

Grafana Beyla, powered by eBPF and OpenTelemetry, combined with Prometheus promises to generate first class observability signals for services regardless of the language and frameworks used. We will walk through deploying Beyla for a homelab, and the challenges in having good observability even with Beyla.

We will walk through:

1. Deploying Beyla in your environment with Prometheus
2. Setting up dashboards for the data
3. Robust alerting over the signals, especially in low, sporadic traffic (homelab) scenarios.
4. The missing signals from eBPF and how you can fill those gaps

sessions.title: EKS Cost Optimization: Deciding Between EC2 and Fargate
sessions.description: Demystifies the complex world of Kubernetes cost optimization on AWS. Through real-world case studies, we'll examine the critical tradeoffs between EC2 and Fargate deployments, and dive deep into Fargate's internal architecture and implementation details. I will go into the details of how AWS engineered Fargate managed service, shedding light on its performance characteristics and cost implications.

sessions.title: Elevate Your Infrastructure - Exploring Crossplane's Full Potential
sessions.description: Crossplane (https://www.crossplane.io/) and its user experience has matured greatly over the years and there are now numerous layers you can interact with while designing and building your internal developer platform powered by Crossplane. Should you directly declare the cloud resources you want Crossplane to create, should you create developer friendly simplified abstractions on top, should you stick with YAML or use a more full featured high level programming language?  We will explore each of these layers in further detail through live demos to understand and efficiently harness the capabilities and experience of each. This will be a broad tour through the possibilities offered by Crossplane, all of which lead to a reliable and robust control plane to manage everything in the cloud that your organization could need!

sessions.title: Elevating IaC with Kubernetes Operators
sessions.description:
Discover how to empower developers to seamlessly integrate with your IaC ecosystem using Kubernetes Operators. Learn how to implement GitOps workflows for deploying cloud components and extend IaC capabilities with operators, enhancing platform subsystem management.

Related Tools:
  - Pulumi
  - Terraform
  - Kubernetes Operator
  - GitHub Actions

sessions.title: Empowering Developers: Building an Application Catalogue with Crossplane
sessions.description: This session features an introduction to platform engineering and a technical demo to help you discover how platform engineering innovations are revolutionizing internal developer platforms. Join us to explore how the open-source CNCF-Project Crossplane enables seamless application catalog construction, empowering teams to streamline development workflows and accelerate innovation. Don't miss this opportunity to see Crossplane and its impact on internal developer platforms and platform engineering.

sessions.title: End-to-End Pull Request Testing on Kubernetes: A Walkthrough
sessions.description:
As applications increasingly rely on Kubernetes for deployment, ensuring seamless integration and end-to-end testing during pull requests is crucial. This talk dives into the practical steps of building a robust CI/CD pipeline that mirrors production environments, enabling reliable and efficient testing within your Kubernetes ecosystem.

We’ll explore how to:

* Set up foundational unit and integration tests using modern tools like Testcontainers and GitHub Workflows.
* Integrate Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) to emulate a production-grade cluster for testing.
* Leverage vCluster to isolate test environments, ensuring parallel runs and minimizing interference.
* Attendees will gain actionable insights to create scalable and maintainable testing pipelines via an existing working example. 

Depending on the audience, I can focus more on a aspect or another.

sessions.title: Escaping the DevOps Hamster Wheel of Busywork
sessions.description:
Is your role slowly morphing into a "bullshit job"? Your automation saved the company millions – but nobody noticed. You became "yes person" to every stakeholder request – but they remember downtime more. You are responsible for problems other people made – but have no authority to fix them permanently. Your time is finite – but the expectations & "urgent" demand aren't.

It's time to break free from endless cycle of firefighting, non-strategic work, and death by a thousand meetings plaguing DevOps professionals. 

In this real talk with no sugarcoating lets put up defenses defenses against the corporate bullshit:
- Cut through corporate noise and focus on work that matters
- Set boundaries and manage scope creep without burning bridges
- Make your impact visible to decision makers
- Identify toxic patterns before they consume your time
- Create space for meaningful work in high-pressure environments
- Keep your sanity in high-pressure environments.

No vague advice. No "just say no.". For DevOps professionals ready to get off the hamster wheel and start driving real value.

sessions.title: Exploring WASM on Kubernetes
sessions.description:
WebAssembly (WASM) is transforming application deployment and execution in cloud environments, offering a lightweight and portable solution that enhances performance and security. In this session, we will explore the potential of WASM in Kubernetes, emphasizing its ability to improve interoperability and streamline microservices architecture.

We will take a closer look at a small terminal and web-based chat application entirely built and deployed using WASM and the WebAssembly System Interface (WASI). Through this example, I will share my learnings from hands-on experimentation, demonstrating how WASM can be leveraged to create highly scalable and efficient microservices. We will discuss practical use cases, the benefits of using WASM for cloud-native applications, and the challenges encountered during implementation.

Join me to discover how WASM can empower your cloud strategy and unlock new possibilities for your applications, all while showcasing a real-world application that highlights its capabilities.

sessions.title: Facing the Monolith: Containerization Challenges and Best Practices for Legacy Apps
sessions.description:
Many organizations face significant challenges when it comes to modernizing legacy applications. This talk dives into the potential of containerization as a key technique for deconstructing monolithic legacy systems and paving the way for a robust microservices architecture. 
We will cover the unique challenges involved in containerizing legacy applications, including platform compatibility issues, complex dependency management, and effective testing strategies. Attendees will gain valuable insights into overcoming these hurdles through real-world examples and best practices. By the end of this session, you'll be equipped with the knowledge and tools to start your own containerization journey, unlocking the full potential of your applications and driving your organization towards a more modern, scalable, and agile future.

sessions.title: Fast Serverless Deployments with Helm: Bypassing the Overhead of Kubernetes and Terraform
sessions.description:
Kubernetes often introduces unnecessary complexity, especially for early-stage companies and serverless-focused teams. In this session, you’ll learn how Helm Charts can serve as a faster, more agile GitOps alternative to Terraform for serverless deployments. Explore a real-world case study showing how a small platform team completely bypassed Kubernetes, achieving a tenfold increase in deployment frequency and a 95% reduction in deployment time.

Attendees will learn how a custom Helm Chart and CI/CD pipeline render Google Cloud Run specifications, decoupling container deployments from Terraform and creating a streamlined, Kubernetes-like developer experience without the overhead.

Gain insights into a flexible, cloud-agnostic model that boosts deployment speed, reduces IaC complexity, and offers early-stage teams an efficient, Kubernetes-free path to scalable, serverless cloud-native infrastructure.

sessions.title: Fixing Resource Labeling: Tying Infrastructure Metadata to Backstage with Terraform
sessions.description:
Consistent and accurate resource labeling is essential in cloud environments. However, manual or inconsistent practices often result in labels that are incomplete, outdated, or inaccurate.

Learn how to restructure and label infrastructure using Backstage components as the source of truth for metadata. With an open-source Terraform provider for Backstage, metadata and labels are automatically injected, keeping them consistent and up-to-date with every plan. To ensure reliability, a metadata wrapper module was developed, and the provider’s resiliency enhanced, preventing Backstage outages from disrupting deployments.

This session will provide a clear understanding of how to integrate Terraform with Backstage to enable automated label injection by structuring infrastructure around components. Attendees will also gain actionable insights to bridge the gap between infrastructure management and the Backstage metadata catalog.

sessions.title: From a Lambda-Lith to an Event Driven Architecture – Lessons Learned
sessions.description:
Are you on a serverless journey on AWS, starting with the popular stack of Amazon ApiGateway, AWS Lambda, and Amazon DynamoDB? While this combination is a simple way to get started, it can quickly become a monolithic and unmaintainable solution. If so, it's time to discover the power of Event-Driven Architectures (EDAs). In this talk, you will learn about the challenges of the "Lambda-Lith" approach and the benefits of embracing EDAs. We will showcase different solution architectures, discussing their trade-offs and sharing valuable insights gained from real-world experiences.

During this session, you will develop a comprehensive understanding of essential EDA concepts, such as the significance of idempotency and its implementation on AWS. You will dive deep on the practical aspects of constructing serverless EDAs on AWS, harnessing the capabilities of AWS EventBridge and AWS Step Functions. Furthermore, we will showcase how to seamlessly incorporate approval workflows using AWS Step Functions.

Throughout the talk, we will address common pitfalls we have taken so you can avoid them. By the end of this session, you will be equipped with the knowledge and practical guidance needed to harness the full potential of event-driven architectures on AWS, enabling you to build scalable, modular, and maintainable serverless applications.

sessions.title: From Chaos to Clarity: Centralizing Observability with OpenSearch at Scale
sessions.description:
Ever faced the challenge of fragmented observability practices, with multiple data sources, teams, and business needs?

We managed to tackle this by transitioning to OpenSearch, leveraging its flexibility and scalability to centralize observability across our production environments while cutting 40% cost – because who doesn’t love saving money?

In this talk, we’ll explore why we chose OpenSearch over SaaS Solutions and how we implement it in our Production Scale as a one-stop shop for Observability by integrating OpenTelemetry (oTel), combining traces, logs, and metrics into a unified solution to deliver deeper insights and actionable analytics.

From practical steps to lessons learned, you will gain actionable insights into building scalable, secure observability solutions with OpenSearch.

This session is tailored for search practitioners, DevOps engineers, platform architects, and anyone interested in building scalable, secure observability solutions with OpenSearch.

sessions.title: From Cloud-First to Cloud-Native: Transitioning Edge Platforms with Kubernetes and OSS Tools
sessions.description: Modern organizations often face the challenge of transitioning from tightly integrated hyperscaler platforms to more flexible, cloud-native solutions. In this talk, I’ll share the journey of a recent project to migrate a customer’s hyperscaler-centric edge device control system to a cloud-native Kubernetes platform. The project involved deploying Kubernetes clusters using an on-premise cloud orchestration platform, replacing managed hyperscaler services like real-time streaming, serverless functions, message queues, relational databases, and in-memory caching with cloud-native alternatives such as EMQX, OpenFaaS, RabbitMQ, PostgreSQL, and Redis. This session goes beyond technical configurations and focuses on the human and operational aspects: the cognitive load on the customer, the effort required for redesigning workflows, and the unforeseen challenges in moving to a decentralized, self-managed ecosystem.

sessions.title: From Code to Leadership: Navigating the Tech Landscape as a Woman
sessions.description: Navigating the tech landscape as a woman comes with unique challenges and opportunities. "From Code to Leadership: Navigating the Tech Landscape as a Woman" offers a comprehensive guide to career growth, leadership development, and the impact of diversity in technology. This presentation provides practical advice for women aspiring to transition from technical roles to leadership positions, emphasizing the importance of continuous learning, mentorship, and building a personal brand.

sessions.title: From EC2 to Kubernetes: Takeaways from a brownfield migration
sessions.description:
This is a case study on how we (Octopus Deploy) migrated our SaaS product from Windows VMs to Kubernetes.  

When we launched our SaaS product, each customer received a dedicated Windows VM, which proved very costly and had many scalability issues. Kubernetes appeared to be the best option, but getting to Kubernetes was the real challenge.

This session will discuss the entire journey of our migration endeavor, from the nine-month conversion phase to the ongoing challenges encountered in the post-migration landscape. Topics discussed will be migrating existing customers, cloud infrastructure, creating efficient deployment strategies, and fine-tuning resource allocation to align with individual customer usage patterns.

With our new managed services architecture and Kubernetes, we are able to easily onboard 100s of new customers per month with little to no adjustments to our platform.

Key Takeaways for Attendees:
- Insights into the rationale behind transitioning from EC2 instances to Kubernetes.
- The rationale behind opting for managed services for our database and file storage needs.
- Challenges encountered during the transition from hosting on Windows to a Linux-based container environment.
- Navigating deployment challenges, leveraging "dogfooding" strategies, and implementing release rings.
- Techniques for dynamically adjusting CPU and RAM resources based on customer usage metrics.

sessions.title: From Terrform to Crossplane: A Kubernetes-Native IaC Evolution
sessions.description:
Everything is possible with Crossplane what you do today with Terraform. 
In this session, we dive into Crossplane use cases and make a brief comparison with Terraform.
Finally, we present a real-time demo

sessions.title: From zero to developer: my one year serendipity journey with OpenTelemetry
sessions.description: Becoming a contributor to an open-source project is a transformative step in any developer's career. This session explores the journey from first-time contributor to active developer, covering best practices for navigating project communities, understanding codebases, and making meaningful contributions. Learn strategies for selecting the right project, mastering collaboration tools, and embracing the culture of open-source development. The audience will be inspired about my one year journey with the open source project  OpenTelemetry and how I have built a proof of concept for it and achieved developer status for this project. By the end of this talk, the public will gain insights into the tools to become a better developer and how to build more engagement with the community.

sessions.title: Fun with Flags: Bringing the Fun Back into Feature Flagging with OpenFeature
sessions.description:
Feature flags have revolutionized the software delivery lifecycle, enabling teams to decouple releases from deployments and create a more agile development process. They're often hailed as one of the key practices in modern software development—at least in theory.

However, as systems grow in complexity, so do the challenges associated with feature flagging. From supporting multiple languages and managing targeted evaluations to avoiding vendor lock-in and safely decommissioning obsolete code, what initially seems like a straightforward problem can quickly become daunting.

The OpenFeature community is tackling these challenges head-on by providing vendor-agnostic SDKs and a suite of powerful tools designed to simplify the feature flagging experience. Join me as we explore the common pitfalls of feature flagging and discover how OpenFeature can help bring the fun back into this critical aspect of software development.

sessions.title: Future-Proofing Infrastructure Security: Machine Identity in Multi-Agent Systems
sessions.description: As organizations deploy increasingly sophisticated AI systems, robust identity management becomes critical. This session explores the evolution from static credential management to dynamic, context-aware machine identity systems. Using Teleport's Machine Identity implementation as a case study, we'll examine how to secure complex scenarios, including multi-agent systems, federated AI operations, and agent-to-agent authentication. The talk will provide practical guidance on implementing cryptographically verifiable identities, managing certificate lifecycles, and maintaining comprehensive audit trails in distributed environments. Attendees will gain insights into emerging patterns for AI agent security, including techniques for managing agent-spawned workloads, implementing cross-organizational trust, and maintaining security at scale. The session includes hands-on examples of configuring machine identity for AI workloads and implementing fine-grained access controls using modern PAM principles.

sessions.title: Gotta’ go FaaSt - observability for Lambdas
sessions.description:
For most applications, sending telemetry data is easy: You instrument your application, and it will either send the data on its way or wait for it to be scraped. This works well, as it’s usually not imperative that the data is transmitted off as soon as possible. This is not the case for AWS Lambda. Every millisecond counts and will show up on your bill at the end of the month. So how can we gather deep application insights while keeping the execution time low?

This talk covers the fundamentals of the AWS Lambda runtime, extension API and how to effectively utilize the gained knowledge in setting up a complete observability solution for Lambdas based on the OpenTelemetry Collector.

sessions.title: Green Kubernetes: Optimizing for Carbon Efficiency
sessions.description:
This session examines strategies for transforming Kubernetes clusters into energy-efficient platforms through carbon-aware scheduling and intelligent workload management. Drawing from documented case studies of European data centers, we'll explore implementations that have achieved 20-35% emission reductions using Kubernetes custom resources. We'll analyze architectural patterns for power monitoring using Prometheus and Grafana, and examine the integration of carbon intensity data into scheduling decisions.

The presentation will cover proven implementation patterns, common pitfalls in power measurement, and methods for building a business case using concrete metrics. Attendees will learn about practical approaches to measure, monitor, and optimize cluster carbon footprint, with access to reference architectures and configuration examples that can be implemented in their environments.

sessions.title: Hands-on with Ray on Kubernetes
sessions.description:
The rapidly evolving landscape of Machine Learning and Large Language Models demands efficient scalable ways to run distributed workloads to train, fine-tune and serve models. Ray is an Open Source framework that simplifies distributed machine learning, and Kubernetes streamlines deployment.
In thise hands-on session we will explore Ray as a framework and how it integrates with Kubernetes to run scalable distributed machine learning workloads. We will cover Ray scalability, patterns for running RayJobs and RayServe and will cover best practices for creating multi-tenant ML platforms using Ray on Kubernetes with fair-sharing of scarce hardware accelerators.we'll uncover how to combine Ray and Kubernetes for your ML projects.

sessions.title: Harbor - OCI Registry done right
sessions.description: When there are images, there needs to be a registry. Many people use proprietary solutions like artifactory or jfrog or the default docker registry with next to none features. In this talk we will take a deeper look into Harbor and it's many features and how they can ne used not only for images, but also for Helm-Charts and other OCI artifacts.

sessions.title: Harnessing Microsoft Copilot: Revolutionizing Workflows with Generative AI
sessions.description:
In this session, participants will explore the transformative power of Microsoft Copilot, a groundbreaking tool leveraging Generative AI to redefine productivity and decision-making in the workplace. 

Designed for professionals across domains, the talk will demystify Copilot’s capabilities and showcase actionable strategies for integrating it into day-to-day operations.

Key Takeaways:
1. Understanding Microsoft Copilot:

Overview of Copilot’s capabilities across Microsoft 365 apps, including Word, Excel, Teams, and PowerPoint.
How Copilot transforms routine tasks into innovative solutions.

2. Real-World Applications:

Demonstrating Copilot’s potential to automate document creation, manage meetings, generate insights, and streamline collaboration.
Use cases tailored for industries such as sales, marketing, HR, and operations.

3. Leveraging Copilot for Collaboration:

Using AI to facilitate seamless communication in Microsoft Teams.
Co-authoring and enhancing content creation with real-time Copilot suggestions.

4. Data-Driven Decision Making with Excel & Power BI:

Harnessing Copilot to build dynamic reports, automate data insights, and optimize business forecasting.

5. The Future of AI in the Workplace:

Ethical considerations and the role of responsible AI adoption.
Emerging trends and how Copilot aligns with the future of hybrid work.

sessions.title: Houston, We Have Observability: A Space-Age Guide to OpenTelemetry
sessions.description:
Launch your observability mission with our space station monitoring application! Watch as life support, navigation, and communication microservices come together in a distributed system that demonstrates three OpenTelemetry approaches: true auto-instrumentation requiring zero code changes, streamlined programmatic instrumentation, and high-precision manual instrumentation.
Learn to instrument your distributed universe with minimal effort, track requests across service boundaries, and diagnose anomalies at warp speed.
Remember: in space, no one can hear your services scream... unless you've properly instrumented them with OpenTelemetry!

sessions.title: How not to use the Kubernetes API when deploying at scale
sessions.description:
The Kubernetes API is awesome and so tempting to use, especially when building Observability Solutions. Nobody wants to just get raw IP addresses and ports in their network or request telemetry, it’s much better to see your pod and service metadata. But what’s even better is that getting information about all the nodes in your cluster can help you produce amazing service graphs.

This talk is a story of how we took down the Kubernetes API in our biggest production cluster at Grafana, by deploying observability tools which make heavy use of the Kubernetes API.

sessions.title: How to Build a Multi-Tenancy Internal Developer Platform with GitOps and vCluster
sessions.description:
An Internal Developer Platform is more than just a user interface or a set of APIs. It is about creating the core functionality that enables self-service for development teams. In this talk, we will show how GitOps and vCluster can help build a scalable and cost-efficient platform that supports multiple teams.

What makes this approach exciting is that we will use tools that the customer already had in place at the enterprise level. The goal was to create a first version of the platform that fits into the existing environment instead of introducing completely new technology.

sessions.title: How to Conquer Observability in Private Clouds? Start Small and Think Big
sessions.description:
In the realm of private clouds, implementing robust observability can seem like an insurmountable challenge. This talk explores our journey of gradually moving from zero to stable observability in the context of private clouds. 
We present how we built observability around our Kubernetes environments, using ArgoCD and Helm for deployments. We examine in detail how we monitor our applications with OpenTelemetry agent for instrumentation and Jaeger Collector for distributed tracing. 
One of the challenges consisted that adding instrumentation also caused significant application performance degradation, which we solved by adding the protobuf extension. Adding profiling signals within the OpenTelemetry would represent a major improvement and solve this bottleneck, as described in our Github issue #4255. 
Attendees will gain insights on how to implement an observability solution in private clouds using open-source tools such as Grafana, Prometheus, OpenTelemetry and Jaeger.

sessions.title: How to make an AI introduction feasible & successful (adoption)
sessions.description: Practical experience reports, tips, good and bad measures for the successful introduction of AI tools.

sessions.title: How to Optimize Non-Coding Time
sessions.description:
This talk is unique because 99% of developer productivity tools and hacks are about coding faster, better, smarter. And yet the vast majority of our time is spent doing all of this other stuff. After I started focusing on optimizing the 10 hours I spend every day on non-coding tasks, I found I my productivity went up and my frustration at annoying stuff went way down.

I cover how to save time by reducing cognitive load and by cutting menial, non-coding tasks that we have to perform 10-50 times every day. For example:

Bug or hotfix comes through and you want to start working on it right away so you create a branch and start fixing. What you don’t do is create a Jira ticket but then later your boss/PM/CSM yells at your due to lack of visibility. I share how I automated ticket creation in Slack by correlating Github to Jira.

You have 20 minutes until your next meeting and you open a pull request and start a review. But you get pulled away half way through and when you come back the next day you forgot everything and have to start over. Huge waste of time. I share an ML job I wrote that tells me how long the review will take so I can pick PRs that fit the amount of time I have.

You build. You ship it. You own it. Great. But after I merge my code I never know where it actually is. Did the CI job fail? Is it release under feature flag? Did it just go GA to everyone? I share a bot I wrote that personally tells me where my code is in the pipeline after it leaves my hands so I can actually take full ownership without spending tons of time figuring out what code is in what release.

sessions.title: How to run a WebAssembly application professionally
sessions.description: WebAssembly has become a relevant player also on the server side for cloud native applications. But how does that actually work? How do you deploy, maintain, configure and secure a server-side WebAssembly application? In this session, we will use a Bluesky verification tool (https://verifiedbsky.net) as case study and look into the relevant topics. As it is built with Spin, we will look at both the Fermyon Cloud and the open source SpinKube framework (recent CNCF addition) as potential deployment targets.

sessions.title: How we progressively deliver changes to Kubernetes using Canary Deployments and Feature Flags
sessions.description:
This is the case study of how we changed how we ship software. 

With thousands of customers, each in their own Kubernetes container, deploying updates was tough. Off-hours schedules meant it took over 24 hours to push a new version. If something broke, we had to scramble. Canary deployments let us update small groups of customers at a time. We built a tool to stop rollouts fast when issues appeared, limiting the damage.

In the past, new features went to everyone at once. Rolling back wasn't an option.  If something failed it'd leave customers stuck in the mess. Now, using OpenFeature, we hide new functionality behind feature flags. We release features to small groups, gather feedback, and test internally for weeks. If things go wrong, we flip the flag off and move on.

This two-pronged approach lets us avoid risky big-bang releases. We went from deploying every 10 days to every 4, with fewer than 1% high-severity defects.  Most of these are resolved before customers notice them.

sessions.title: How we used Crossplane for the things we should not have
sessions.description:
Frameworks are meant to be tweaked, that is just a part of being an engineer. Even if a new cloud native, open source framework is exactly what you are attempting to build. 
This talk tells the story of what Crossplane is and what we wanted it to be. It highlights the need for the emerging Crossplane V2, and why they are different. It also illustrates a real life story when bending leads to breaking, with losing 230 production databases for a customer during maintenance. The silver lining - we kept the customer, but changed our approach.

sessions.title: Identity in a Cloud Native AI Landscape
sessions.description: When integrating AI with Cloud Native systems, lack of planning can lead you to the dystopian reality. What would a plan for such a system look like? We look how existing methods from policy enforcement to best practices can/could be implemented using today's CNAI technologies.
