For example, how can a "best practice" such as Zero Trust be implemented in the CNAI world. How about regulations and compliance? With a little planning, use of AI can improve our system and business operations.

sessions.title: Implementing Fine-Grained Authorization in Microservices with OPAL and OPA: A Real-World Journey
sessions.description:
Authorization is one of the most complex challenges in cloud-native architectures. In this session, I'll share my practical experience implementing Open Policy Agent (OPA) with Open Policy Administration Layer (OPAL) to create a federated, fine-grained authorization system that balances domain ownership with centralized governance.

I'll walk through our complete implementation journey, focusing on:


Architecture: How we adapted the standard OPAL architecture to create a federated policy management system with domain-specific ownership while maintaining centralized governance


Policy Distribution: Our CI/CD pipeline for policy synchronization across environments and GitLab webhook integration for real-time policy updates via OPAL


Service Integration: How we abstracted policy evaluation from domain services using custom Spring Security annotations and Spring Expression Language, creating a clean separation of concerns


Operational Excellence: Our monitoring setup for tracking authorization decisions and troubleshooting in production


Through concrete code examples and architectural diagrams, you'll see how our approach empowered domain teams to own their authorization logic while maintaining security governance and operational visibility across the organization.

sessions.title: InfraOps Autonomy with Decentralized Devops
sessions.description:
In this Session, I will explain and walk you through on below essential topics, problem statements, and how we mitigated it with Terraform, Azure Devops, and ITSM Process. 

1. What is Decentralized Devops and why it is an growing requirement in very organisation ?

2. Decentralized Devops and FOMO ?

3. Self Service - Definition ?

4. Can Self Service be achieved from Technology/Tooling alone ?

5. Sneak Peak on Self Service ?

6. Why Hashicorp Terraform  Product for Self Service ?

I not only showcase the Problem statements but also help you explore your options by presenting the approach with which, we are trying to resolve.

sessions.title: Infrastructure from Code: The Next Generation of Cloud Management
sessions.description: While Infrastructure as Code (IaC) has become the standard for managing cloud resources using tools like Terraform, Pulumi, and Bicep, writing templates can still be a time-consuming task. But what if infrastructure could be automatically inferred from your application code? In this session, we’ll explore the emerging concept of "Infrastructure from Code" and evaluate the maturity of tools like Radius, Dapr, and Nitric. Are these tools ready to replace IaC? Join us to find out if it’s time to make the leap to a more seamless infrastructure experience.

sessions.title: Internal Developer Platforms are failing, let's fix it.
sessions.description:
A lot of companies start looking into Internal Developer Platforms as the next hype cycle suggests. However, building those platforms is not an easy task, and companies who did it often struggle on the way and sometimes even regret the investment. 

Join my journey where I looked into various companies, talked to fellow engineers, and reflected on my own past struggles to build an IDP.

Learn the pitfalls and principles of successful IDPs in this session. We will explore assessing the value of IDPs, understanding their role in developer self-service, and making informed decisions about whether they align with your organization's goals.

sessions.title: Jarvis in the Cluster: Building Your K8s AI Assistant with Argo Events
sessions.description:
What happens when Argo Events, Argo Workflows, and Tekton Pipelines join forces? We've created a Kubernetes automation system that doesn't just react, it anticipates. Our demo features "K8-Bit," a playful AI assistant that translates casual developer requests into sophisticated event chains and deployment workflows. Watch as a simple "ship it" command triggers intelligent repository analysis, custom pipeline assembly, and self-healing infrastructure responses.
In this session, we'll cover: event-driven architecture fundamentals, Argo Events' sensor/trigger model, live K8-Bit demonstrations, and practical integration patterns between Argo and Tekton. You'll learn how to build an event mesh spanning your entire delivery lifecycle that creates truly adaptive GitOps without sacrificing governance or declarative principles.

sessions.title: Korifi: Cloud Foundry as a PaaS for Kubernetes
sessions.description: Use Cloud Foundry abstractions to enable platform engineering with "push to deploy" for developers on a Kubernetes platform.

sessions.title: KRO: A New Way to Manage Kubernetes and Cloud Resources
sessions.description:
Kubernetes lacks a native way for platform teams to create custom groupings of resources for end users to consume. AWS started a project to simplify this, and it is now officially supported by Google Cloud and Azure. KRO (Kube Resource Operator) creates abstractions to encapsulate complex Kubernetes resources, allows the grouping of applications and their dependencies as a single, easily consumable resource, and orchestrates them. Although the project is in a very early development phase, it promises a good solution.

This session will explore how KRO allows developers and platform engineers to define and manage Kubernetes and AWS resources declaratively. We will demonstrate how KRO streamlines resource provisioning, enhances GitOps workflows and reduces operational overhead.

sessions.title: Kubenix: Declare Your K8s Workloads Fully Reproducible
sessions.description:
Kubenix allows the generation of Kubernetes manifests by leveraging Nix modules.
On top of OpenAPI, Kubenix exposes the core Kubernetes API for the functional language Nix.
This enables a fully declarative description of Kubernetes workloads with the best reproducibility, thus making YAML templating obsolete.
Kubenix's Helm wrapper provides access to the large ecosystem of the de-facto package manager for Kubernetes while preserving Nix's qualities.
With the ability to build reproducible OCI container images with Nix, Kubenix both simplifies and improves the definition of Kubernetes workloads.
After briefly introducing Nix itself, this talk will showcase Kubenix with practical use cases ranging from simple Kubernetes manifests to complex application stacks.
Let's make our Kubernetes workloads both declarative and reproducible!

sessions.title: Lessons learned: Two years of GitOps with FluxCD in production
sessions.description: I've been working on a project for two years now, which was already using GitOps with FluxCD. In this talk I'll show our current GitOps setup and how new features make their way into production through our three stages. I will show the benefits, such as better reproducibility and efficiency, but also discuss the challenges and drawbacks: from complex defect analysis to organisational stumbling blocks. I also look ahead to where we see potential for improvement. This candid testimonial offers practical insights and lessons learned for anyone looking to evaluate or develop GitOps.

sessions.title: Lightning Talk: Service Mesh in 2025: What We Gained, What We Lost, and What We Regret at 3 A.M
sessions.description:
Service mesh was supposed to be the answer. The great orchestrator of microservices, the peacekeeper of distributed systems, the babysitter who makes sure nobody takes more than their share of the cookies. But as we step into 2025, we have to ask—did we get what we signed up for? Or did we just trade one set of problems for another, wrapped in YAML?

This talk takes a real, unfiltered look at the state of service mesh in 2025. What actually changed with Ambient Mesh? Did getting rid of sidecars really make life easier, or did we just move the pain to a place we haven’t noticed yet? And what about Cilium and eBPF—is this the revolution we were promised, or just a different kind of complexity with a fancier name?

We’ll talk zero trust, because apparently, nothing—not even our own services—deserves faith anymore. We’ll look at the great migration away from sidecars, and whether it’s leading us to a golden age of networking or just another round of debugging nightmares at 3 a.m.

This session is part technical review, part retrospective, and all brutal honesty—with a touch of humor to help us all cope. Whether you love service mesh, hate it, or are just trying to survive it, you’ll walk away with a better understanding of where we are, how we got here, and what it all really means.

sessions.title: Local Development made easy
sessions.description: Everybody has been there, you add a new feature, it works on your machine but not in production. This happens often, because local environments are different to production.  Yes, local development for Kubernetes application can be tedious sometimes, as you spent more time on setting up infrastructure than actual testing. Learn in this session how we at Dynatrace use tools like Skaffold, Helm and others to develop applications.

sessions.title: Managed Kubernetes Services - a multi-region setup for disaster recovery
sessions.description: How to use CDN Services, Managed Kubernetes Services and Keda to automate the activation of a Disaster Recovery solution without duplicating infrastructure costs.

sessions.title: Many Cooks, One Platform:  Balancing Ownership and Contribution for the Perfect Broth
sessions.description:
When I started contracting with the Dutch government to build a new internal developer platform, I found myself navigating competing demands from different teams. Development teams wanted support tailored to their processes, neighboring infrastructure teams aimed to protect their areas of responsibility, and management expected visible progress. These conflicting priorities kept pulling my team in multiple directions, making it challenging to stay aligned and focused.

Since I have a background in Developer Relations, I soon made it my goal to engage all involved parties, giving users a sense of ownership and collaboration, while keeping the platform cohesive.

In this talk, I’ll share the tools and processes that helped address these challenges. I’ll provide practical insights for aligning diverse stakeholders. If you’ve ever faced the challenge of “too many cooks” this session will show how to turn competing demands into a recipe for success.

sessions.title: Mastering Data Governance: Security, Compliance, and Visibility
sessions.description:
As data security and compliance requirements become increasingly complex, organizations must implement strong data governance to protect sensitive information. This session delves into Snowflake’s powerful governance capabilities, including data quality monitoring, column- and row-level security, object tagging, and sensitive data classification.

Attendees will gain hands-on experience with key governance features, learning how to apply masking policies, enforce access controls, and track data activity using audit logs and access history. A live demo and interactive tutorial will showcase how to monitor and manage governance policies through Snowsight’s governance dashboard.

By the end of the session, participants will have actionable strategies to enhance data security, maintain compliance, and ensure data integrity at scale within their Snowflake environments.

sessions.title: Mastering Modern Software Distribution: On-Prem, Air-Gapped, and BYOC Challenges
sessions.description:
Distributing software across on-premises, air-gapped systems, and bring-your-own-cloud (BYOC) setups presents unique challenges. During this talk Philip will share his experiences and learnings from helping companies distribute their software from binaries to Helm charts.

For each of the following chapters we will dive into live examples showcasing common errors and proposing fixes that will be immediately applied and tested.

- Packaging Strategies: Semantic versioning, build automation, and dependency management.

- Secure Artifact Distribution: Using OCI registries to restrict image tag access, attach SBOMs and regularly scan for CVEs.

- Pre-Flight and Target Assessments: Preparing for complex environments with configuration validation and air-gapped packaging.

- Deployment Methods: Comparing binaries, Docker images, Helm charts, and BYOC models.

- Security and Application Boundaries: Securing Kubernetes deployments with namespaced vs. cluster-scoped installations.

- Lifecycle Management: Updating installations, managing licenses, and communicating with teams.

We also plan to have enough time for Q&A so we can address real-world deployment challenges from the audience live on stage.

sessions.title: Mission: Impossible - Building Self-Healing Disaster Recovery with OpenFeature
sessions.description:
Imagine presenting to your dream clients when your primary region decides to take a coffee break. That's exactly what happened to us - 25 minutes of unexpected manual failover, and watching hope drain from our team's & audience's faces. Our multi-region setup was more "disaster" than "recovery".

Join this talk as Prerit walk us over how they build an intelligent feature flag orchestration platform using OpenFeature which now processes 1k flag evaluations/second across 3 global regions, reduced infrastructure incident risk by 90% & DR time from 25 minutes to 125 seconds and has successfully handled 15 regional incidents without a single lost transaction. 

We will also see they built the "infrastructure gates" to control traffic shifting with millisecond precision, feature state synchronization, and WARM-HOT-COLD DR strategies with just a toggle.

sessions.title: Navigating the Copilot Universe: Your Guide to Microsoft’s AI Landscape
sessions.description:
Confused by the diverse range of products and names associated with Microsoft’s Copilot brand? This session is your ticket to understanding it all! We’ll take you from beginner to expert as we explore the different Copilot offerings and the exciting areas where Microsoft is investing in AI. Discover everything from simple, ready-to-use Copilots to expansive platforms, and learn how to maximize these tools for your projects.

After this session you will understand the differences and dependency between the Copilot products and now, which product to check first, before starting with an individual AI agent.

In addition to the theory, there are always concrete examples and ideas of how customers or I personally use AI in day-to-day operations.

sessions.title: Navigating the Digital Evolution: A Technologist's Guide to Thriving in the Age of Innovation
sessions.description: Unlock the secrets of thriving in tech with a presentation on innovation, skill enhancement, and leadership. Elevate your career and brand on LinkedIn, connecting with pioneers and shaping the future.

sessions.title: Navigating the Open Source Observability Landscape
sessions.description:
In the cloud native era systems are getting ever more dynamic and complex. With containers and microservices architecture, monitoring and troubleshooting systems is more challenging than ever before.

The open source community has risen up to the challenge and has delivered solutions that fit modern environments. Established open source projects such as Prometheus and the ELK Stack have gathered massive adoption, while new projects keep emerging and uncovering yet untapped possibilities such as continuous profiling and eBPF. Alongside tools, open standards, such as OpenMetrics and OpenTelemetry, are emerging to converge the industry and prevent vendor lock-in. Goodness, it’s hard to keep track of all that goodness.

In this talk Horovits, CNCF Ambassador and open observability veteran, will talk about the recommended open source tools and standards for observability (looking also beyond logs, metrics and traces), and how to combine them to help you achieve effective observability in your environment.

sessions.title: Network Assistant: a Multi-Agent GenAI Solution contributing in the Telco to Techco Journey
sessions.description:
Network Assistant: a Multi-Agent GenAI Solution contributing in the Telco to Techco Journey

Agentic generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that possess a degree of autonomy and decision-making capability, enabling them to generate content or solutions based on user input and contextual understanding. They can adapt to changes and learn from interactions, allowing to produce more nuanced and contextually relevant outputs. Multi-agent systems are revolutionising the execution of tasks, facilitating more intelligent, rapid and effective workflows.

Partnering with AWS has fostered our efforts to deploy the Network Assistant, a multi-agent genAI application based in AWS Bedrock able to retrieve data from network entities of multiple data sources and analyse the telemetry metrics to check for compliance, thresholds and faulty elements. The main aim is to eliminate the need for manually checking each of the data sources, provide a clear understanding of network parameters and their correct performance conditions and offer Swisscom engineers valuable insights out of the data.

How are we making the most out of AWS powered Generative AI? Leveraging multiple agents and action groups has allowed to combine diverse data sources and capabilities, while tackling complex tasks and calculations that involve data engineering processes more effectively. This collaboration enhanced the adaptability and responsiveness of our Network Assistant, enabling for richer context-aware outputs and more accurate responses avoiding taking relevant vector embeddings for granted.

If you are interested in:
- Generative AI in AWS environment applied to a big telco.
- AWS Bedrock: our use of knowledge bases, agents and action groups, among other features.
- How data engineering can blend into Generative AI.

Do not hesitate to tune in! 🚀

sessions.title: Next Gen Cost Observability: The Ongoing Journey To Trustworthy Cost Metrics Across CSPs.
sessions.description:
Accurately attributing cloud costs has become a Sisyphean task many companies face. As the cloud evolves, it's hard to figure out what exactly is eating up all that money, let alone optimize costs. In this session, we'll take you through the journey that got us to trustworthy cost metrics for Kubernetes clusters and other cloud resources across 3 cloud providers.
Measuring the trend of costs for cloud resources is easy to get started with. If you are operating Prometheus and collecting metrics from kube-state-metrics, stackdriver-exporter or yet-another-cloudwatch-exporter you likely already have enough data. Joining this with cost metrics brings you into a position to alert early on cost changes and will allow you to mitigate shock bills in cloud providers.
Finally, we will learn how we created a Prometheus exporter, which provides accurate cost metrics for various cloud resources across different cloud providers.

sessions.title: NixOS + Kubernetes: A Match Made in Heaven or Hell?
sessions.description:
NixOS is an immutable Linux-based operating system with an atomic update model, which builds on the Nix package manager.
NixOS is fully declared by the purely functional language Nix and enables the best reproducibility.
As a matter of fact, both NixOS and Kubernetes represent an operating system, with a declarative approach to abstract away system resources and expose an API to define workloads.
Kubernetes is a platform for building platforms and therefore emphasizes distributed systems, while NixOS has more of a host-centric focus.
For this reason, NixOS as a Linux operating system has great potential to complement Kubernetes as a foundation.
After briefly introducing Nix itself, this talk will discuss NixOS as a basis for Kubernetes clusters, starting from a hypervisor up to virtual machines hosting Kubernetes Nodes – all fully declarative with Nix.
Let's find out if NixOS is a useful basis for Kubernetes!

sessions.title: Observability 2.0 - Much more than just logs,metrics and traces
sessions.description:
Observability is changing drastically with wide use of Opentelemetry in modern applications. Now it helps to direclty derive predictions using ML algorithms, finding anomalous logs, using LLM observability and many such things.

Covering how to simply cut down on downtime and troubleshooting time by implementing the Otel Collector, which will ultimately benefit the business.

One of the main issues with observability is cost, which is caused by the massive amount of data that is regularly ingested. To lessen this, people are utilizing data ingestion pipelines in the modern day, which only ingest the necessary data while ignoring unnecessary data.

I will cover most of the changes that have happened in recent times and also will share some insights on how AI will be integrated to automate some tasks and help in error prediction in observability.

sessions.title: OpenSearch: The Open Source Path to Search and Observability
sessions.description:
OpenSearch has become a cornerstone of open source search and observability, empowering developers and organizations to derive meaningful insights from unstructured data at scale. This year marks a significant milestone in its journey, with OpenSearch officially joining The Linux Foundation, further cementing its position in the open source ecosystem.

In this session, we’ll introduce OpenSearch, from vector search and natural language processing to full text semantic search and log analytics and observability capabilities. We’ll share latest improvements in query performance, scalability, and real-time analytics, as well as its expanding ecosystem with new plugins and SDKs in multiple programming languages.

Whether you’re looking for log analytics, to embed search capabilities in your website, or to build AI/ML applications, this is your opportunity to hear it right from the Chief Evangelist of the open source project and discover how OpenSearch can help you.

sessions.title: Optimize The Ever-Elusive Platform ROI
sessions.description: Platform Engineering defines a set of practices targeted at streamlining software delivery, improving engineering experience and the reliability of our systems. But building a great platform comes with a cost. In this talk we'll discuss platform optimization: when to optimize, what to optimize for, and what are some optimization strategies we've seen succeed in the field.

sessions.title: Orchestrating Resilient Data: Harnessing the Strength of Kubernetess with Operators
sessions.description: Embark on a journey into the heart of Kubernetes orchestration as we explore the seamless integration of database solutions, leveraging Kubernetes Operators. Discover how this powerful combination streamlines the deployment, scaling, and management of your database clusters within the dynamic Kubernetes ecosystem. Join us to unravel the intricacies of deploying resilient and scalable data solutions, empowering your applications with agility and efficiency. Learn best practices, real-world insights, and key strategies to unlock the full potential of cloud-native data management, all within the context of Kubernetes excellence. Elevate your understanding of distributed systems and database administration in this engaging session designed for Kubernetes enthusiasts and data aficionados alike.

sessions.title: Paranoid Observability - Success Stories and Misfortunes observing an observability stack
sessions.description:
The benefits of having some form of an observability stack to track the health of production systems is well documented. How would your approach change if your production system is the observability stack? This is the story of how we built out a system to ensure the observability tools watching our customers' production systems were available and able to send alerts when things went wrong.

You’ll learn about common stories around adopting Prometheus to collect metrics and to use Alertmanager to send alerts. Both systems are easy to get started with, so you’ll see how each component can break as they scale. Eventually there is a tipping point where you can no longer scale Prometheus and you’ll learn where to go next.

Finally, you'll learn how to monitor your observability systems in such a way that ensures you will still get alerted when things go wrong. We’ll share the architecture that has taken us from a few clusters in one region, to dozens of clusters running across the globe.

sessions.title: Performance Optimized Spring Boot for the Cloud
sessions.description:
In the era of cloud-native applications, optimizing performance, scalability, and observability is crucial for delivering robust and efficient services. This session will explore best practices for optimizing Spring Boot applications specifically for cloud environments. We will delve into key strategies for enhancing performance, including efficient resource management and asynchronous processing.

Additionally, we will discuss how to implement observability in Spring Boot applications using tools like Spring Actuator, Micrometer, and distributed tracing. Attendees will learn how to monitor application health, track performance metrics, and gain insights into system behavior, enabling proactive troubleshooting and optimization.

By the end of this session, participants will have a comprehensive understanding of how to build and maintain high-performance Spring Boot applications in the cloud, ensuring they can scale effectively while maintaining optimal performance and observability.

sessions.title: Pipelines for IaC: A Luxury or a Must?
sessions.description: In the cult of DevOps, automation is key. But are pipelines for IaC just a nice-to-have, or are they essential for scaling infrastructure practices? This talk explores the critical role of pipelines in delivering robust, repeatable, and efficient IaC processes. Attendees will gain insights into the benefits, challenges, and best practices (including the "WHEN") for implementing pipelines and leave with actionable steps to enhance their DevOps workflows.

sessions.title: Pod Deep Dive: Everything You Didn't Know You Needed to Know
sessions.description:
Kubernetes Pods may be the smallest deployable units in your clusters, but they hold hidden complexities that even seasoned users can overlook. If you think you know everything about Pods — think again!

This talk is designed to take you on a deep dive into the world of all things Pods, covering both the familiar and the obscure. 

Starting with a quick overview of the basic architecture, we’ll then move into more nuanced territory — exploring topics like Pod readiness probes, lifecycle hooks, runtime classes, and the multitude of different container types that can be used. We’ll also discuss common misconceptions, gotchas that can trip you up in production, and offer some best practices suggestions along the way. 

By the end of this session, you’ll have a deeper understanding and appreciation of Pods and the knowledge to leverage them expertly in your Kubernetes clusters.

sessions.title: Practical introduction to OpenTelemetry tracing
sessions.description:
Tracking a request’s flow across different components in distributed systems is essential. With the rise of microservices, their importance has risen to critical levels. Some proprietary tools for tracking have been used already: Jaeger and Zipkin naturally come to mind.

Observability is built on three pillars: logging, metrics, and tracing. OpenTelemetry is a joint effort to bring an open standard to them. Jaeger and Zipkin joined the effort so that they are now OpenTelemetry compatible.

In this talk, I’ll describe the above in more detail and showcase a (simple) use case to demo how you could benefit from OpenTelemetry in your distributed architecture.

sessions.title: Proactive Istio Monitoring: Uplift Your Platform's Reliability and Stability
sessions.description:
Istio has emerged as one of the most prominent service mesh solutions in the Kubernetes ecosystem. However, as new projects onboard to Istio, setting up effective monitoring becomes a critical task. As a tier-0 component of any K8s-based cloud platform, the service mesh plays a vital role in ensuring system stability—and designing the right alerting strategy is essential to prevent revenue-impacting incidents.

At Expedia Group, we conducted an extensive analysis of Istio's observability stack. Our deep dive into the Istio control plane revealed key signals and common failure modes. Using this knowledge, we developed a robust approach to alerting and implemented proactive measures to mitigate potential failures.

In this session, we will share the results of our comprehensive study. Attendees will gain actionable insights into monitoring Istio effectively and understand the best practices for establishing alerts that can safeguard platform reliability.

sessions.title: Proactive Threat Mitigation with Threat Modeler: Securing APIs and Authentication in Azure
sessions.description:
This in-depth session explores how to proactively identify and mitigate security threats in your cloud-native applications.

We will examine common security vulnerabilities such as Authentication Abuse, Malicious Insiders, and Insecure Interfaces and APIs in cloud environments, with a specific focus on Azure-native solutions.

You will learn best practices for securing APIs, including strong authentication, encryption, and API access control, to protect against unauthorized access and data breaches.

We will also highlight how Azure tools like Azure Key Vault and Azure API Management can help securely manage sensitive information and facilitate integration with external systems.

Through practical, real-world examples, we’ll explore how to leverage threat modeling techniques, identify vulnerable interfaces, and apply targeted security controls to defend against common attack vectors.

sessions.title: Provide Interactive Learning Environments with Educates
sessions.description:
Educates is an open-source platform designed to host interactive workshops on Kubernetes clusters. Originally created to assist developer advocates in training users on Kubernetes, it has evolved into a versatile tool suitable for a variety of educational scenarios.

Workshop participants can take advantage of self-paced learning content within a secure, controlled environment, allowing them to explore new technologies and concepts at their own pace.

This session will introduce you to the Educates platform and demonstrate how easy it is to create engaging workshops!

sessions.title: Pull Request Power-Ups: Dynamic CI/CD and On-Demand Environments with Tekton & ArgoCD
sessions.description: Imagine every pull request automatically kicks off its own CI/CD pipeline and runs checks and tests, does linting, and even spins up a full, isolated test environment. In this session, we are going to make that a reality using Pipelines as Code with Tekton and GitOps with ArgoCD. You’ll learn how to dynamically trigger workflows per PR, deploy ephemeral environments on demand, and streamline your review process with personalized PR automation. Whether you're aiming for faster feedback loops or cleaner code merges, this talk will give you the tools to level up your DevOps game with automation, scalability, and speed.

sessions.title: Revolutionizing Healthcare and Life Sciences with Cloud-Native SAP S/4HANA and AI: Operational Excel
sessions.description:
In this session at Cloud Native Summit 2025, we delve into the transformative power of SAP S/4HANA Cloud in driving innovation and operational excellence within healthcare and life sciences organizations. By leveraging cloud-native architecture and advanced AI capabilities, SAP S/4HANA empowers organizations to achieve unprecedented efficiency, compliance, and patient care outcomes.

Key highlights include how this next-generation ERP platform, with its in-memory computing architecture, accelerates transaction processing by up to 10x and provides real-time analytics for mission-critical decisions. Case studies will showcase a 60% reduction in data reconciliation efforts, a 40% boost in data accuracy, and a 148% ROI within three years of adoption. Innovative features such as Extended Warehouse Management have cut batch release times by 40%, while Revenue Accounting and Reporting modules have enhanced insurance claims accuracy by 35%.

The integration of AI-powered predictive analytics and automated resource allocation has further streamlined supply chains, reducing operational costs by 25% while enabling better patient outcomes. Attendees will also learn about cutting-edge implementation strategies, including adaptive data migration, stakeholder training, and change management initiatives that have driven 90% user adoption rates within a year.

Looking ahead, the session explores emerging trends such as IoMT integration and blockchain technology, unlocking new possibilities for sustainable operations and enhanced ERP functionality in the Industry 4.0 era. Attendees will leave equipped with actionable strategies and insights to replicate these successes, harnessing cloud-native innovations to overcome the challenges of modern healthcare and life sciences.

sessions.title: Save Thousands of DevOps Hours: Unleashing the Power of Self-Service
sessions.description:
Are you tired of waiting for DevOps to provision complex AWS, GCP, or Azure stacks? No more! At MyHeritage, we tackled this pain by creating a self-service platform that empowers developers to provision resources independently, freeing DevOps for more meaningful work. We’ll reveal how our Golden Path approach streamlines resource creation, enabling developers to focus on coding and solving business challenges instead of wrestling with infrastructure.

We’ll showcase pre-configured recipes that effortlessly provision cloud resources while embedding organizational standards, defaults, and compliance checks. Developers use high-level code to customize IaC recipes to their needs. GitOps then converts this code into OpenTofu, with IAM policies and configurations prepared by the platform team, and delivers it to production. Join us to discover how this approach eliminates delays and boosts cloud productivity.

sessions.title: Securing Kubernetes: Practical Workflows and Tools for Enhanced Cluster Protection
sessions.description:
An engaging session that delves deep into the world of securing Kubernetes (K8s) clusters through the lens of Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) best practices. In this comprehensive talk, we will guide you through a structured agenda that covers essential aspects of Kubernetes security, providing practical insights and actionable strategies.

The session kicks off with an introduction to Kubernetes security challenges, setting the stage for understanding why securing K8s clusters is paramount in today's dynamic threat landscape. We will then navigate through OWASP's best practices tailored for Kubernetes environments, shedding light on key guidelines to fortify your containerized applications.

Moving into the practical realm, the agenda unfolds to reveal a well-defined workflow for Kubernetes security. Attendees will learn how to seamlessly integrate security practices into their development and deployment lifecycle, striking a balance between speed and security. The discussion will extend into CI/CD integration, showcasing the implementation of automated security testing within pipelines, ensuring continuous security validation.

An integral part of the session is the exploration of cutting-edge tools designed for securing Kubernetes. Live demonstrations will provide a hands-on understanding of tools for vulnerability scanning, runtime protection, and policy enforcement, helping attendees make informed decisions based on their specific needs.

Whether you're a developer, DevOps engineer, or security professional, this session is your gateway to enhancing the security posture of your Kubernetes deployments, guided by OWASP best practices.

sessions.title: Securing production with network polices - What can possible go wrong?
sessions.description:
Network polices are a crucial security layer and essential for defining access policies for communication between pods. 
During my session you will learn how and why you should use network polices. I will give you an overview of currently available options to secure your pod network traffic. I will also demonstrate how to use regular network polices, cluster wide polices and host polices. During the demo we will focus on implementing polices to a running cluster. Showcasing software like Cilium and Hubble which can be extremely helpful in visualising cluster traffic. This talk should help you demystify network polices and give you some great arguments to get started with securing your production cluster.

sessions.title: Securing Web Applications Against OWASP Top 10 Threats in AWS Cloud
sessions.description:
If you are dealing with application security, chances are you are familiar with the Open Worldwide Application Security Project (OWASP) Top 10, a globally acknowledged benchmark for understanding and addressing the most critical security threats impacting modern web applications. This widely recognized framework highlights vulnerabilities that can lead to significant risks if left unaddressed, such as data breaches, unauthorized access, and operational disruptions. While the OWASP Top 10 serves as a foundational guide for securing web applications, it is not a one-size-fits-all solution. Its implementation often requires adapting security measures to specific contexts, particularly as organizations transition to cloud-native environments.

The shift to the cloud introduces a unique landscape of risks that go beyond traditional application security concerns. Factors such as shared responsibility models, dynamic scaling, and decentralized infrastructure demand innovative approaches that blend traditional AppSec practices with cloud-native solutions. These new challenges highlight the need for tools and methodologies designed to operate seamlessly within the complexities of modern cloud ecosystems, ensuring that web applications remain secure while supporting organizational agility and growth.

In this session, we will delve into leveraging AWS-native tools to mitigate OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities effectively. Attendees will walk away with a comprehensive understanding of how to secure web applications in AWS using cloud-native tools. By shifting the focus of "securing in the cloud" responsibilities to application security (AppSec) teams and leveraging AWS-native solutions to handle "securing on the cloud," this approach enables organizations to mitigate OWASP Top 10 threats effectively.

Whether you are a Cloud Security Architect, CloudOps Engineer, DevOps practitioner or Platform Engineer, this session will equip you with actionable insights and best practices to build secure, scalable, and resilient web applications in AWS. By the end, you’ll be prepared to tackle the evolving complexities of cloud-native security with confidence and precision.

sessions.title: Serverless is above limits? Our Path to production database cluster.
sessions.description:
We live in an era driven by information, and success in business is increasingly dependent on the effective management and processing of vast amounts of information. Reliability, scalability, and efficiency are key factors shaping the development of databases.
The technology from AWS has already gained recognition among global financial giants, including S&P Dow Jones Indices, so it's worth checking out what benefits we can achieve in our own projects.
During the lecture, I will share experiences from production deployments of Aurora Serverless v2. I will discuss what challenges related to serverless I encountered, how dynamic scaling and RDS proxy works in practice, and the impact of resources and queries on the performance of the solution.
And most importantly! Whether choosing Aurora serverless v2 is a good decision.
If you're a serverless technology enthusiast, an AWS specialist, or simply looking for innovative solutions in data management, this lecture is for you!

sessions.title: Slash your cloud network costs with eBPF network monitoring
sessions.description:
According to a number of cloud vendor usage studies, cross-availability zone (AZ) data transfers regularly account for at least 25% of the public cloud users’ production cost. Cutting down these costs can affect your bottom line and your application affordability. All major cloud vendors provide daily aggregated cost metrics for the cross-zone network traffic, however oftentimes, these reports lack the granularity of information to tell which pods or workloads are responsible for the elevated cross-zone traffic.

This talk is about using OSS observability tools that will help you effectively identify cross-AZ traffic and allow you to understand how to slash your cloud bill costs.

sessions.title: Smells Like Clean Telemetry: Stop the Noise, Create Better Spans
sessions.description:
You’ve heard about OpenTelemetry, and now it’s time to give it a shot. Instrumenting your services was easy—until it wasn’t. You got some traces flowing into your observability backend, but as soon as you started adding custom spans and attributes, the real questions began.

Should you create spans for every single method/function in your code? Is more always better? What attributes should you add to your spans? Maybe include full JSON payloads, or go all out and add a whole PDF as an attribute? (Spoiler: don’t.)

Join Juliano in this talk to learn best practices for customizing your application instrumentation with OpenTelemetry. Discover how to make the most of your telemetry while ensuring usability, cost efficiency, and performance. Whether you're just starting out or fine-tuning your instrumentation, this session will help you get to the right balance, avoid costly mistakes, and walk away with clear strategies to get the most out of your telemetry.

sessions.title: State of Checkpoint/Restore in Kubernetes - now with GPUs
sessions.description:
In 2023 I gave the presentation "Forensic container checkpointing and analysis". This year's session is the follow-up session to the 2023 session. Since 2023 the checkpointing feature in Kubernetes graduated from Alpha to Beta and with the release of containerd 2.0 it is no longer a CRI-O only feature.

In this session I want to provide an update about the state of Checkpoint/Restore in Kubernetes and also highlight how the feature opens up additional uses cases outside of the forensic use case.

I also want to provide updates how it is now possible to migrate containers using a GPU and close the session with a live demo migrating a container running an LLM with a GPU from one host to another.

sessions.title: Stateful applications in Kubernetes
sessions.description:
Running stateless applications in Kubernetes has multiple proven benefits such as quick deployment and easy upgrade/rollback.

However these benefits can also extend to stateful applications such as databases!

But what special considerations need to be accounted for when deploying stateful applications to Kubernetes?

Join Docker Captain Andrew Pruski in this session to dive into the different options available when deploying stateful applications to Kubernetes.

We will cover the following concepts, using Postgres as an example: -
- What are storage classes, persistent volumes, and persistent volume claims?
- What is the difference between deployments and statefulsets?
- How do we provide high availability for our stateful application?
- Can Helm be used to simplify the deployment of our stateful application?

This session is for anyone who wants to learn more about how to correctly deploy statefule applications to Kubernetes.

sessions.title: Supercharge GitHub Actions with AWS CodeBuild Managed Runners
sessions.description:
Slow builds? Angry devs? Ditch runners pain!
Managing EC2 instances for GitHub Actions runners within your VPC is a major headache: scaling is time-consuming, costly, and introduces operational overhead.

Unmaintained pipelines leading to frustrating delays, creates bottlenecks with the release velocity, and tempting developers to bypass the system with manual deployments. This slows down innovation and increases the risk of errors.
In this talk you will learn how to streamline your CI/CD process and boost developer morale by leveraging CodeBuild's fully managed, serverless environment to execute your GitHub Actions workflows. We'll walk through a real-world migration from a self-managed EKS-based solution to CodeBuild Managed Runners, showcasing key configuration steps, best practices, and addressing common pitfalls.

You'll discover how this integration simplifies infrastructure management, enhances security with native AWS IAM and VPC integration, and dramatically improves operational efficiency. Eliminate the pain of runners and custom images, freeing your DevOps teams to focus on delivering value and empowering developers to trust the pipeline.
This session is tailored for DevOps engineers, DevOps Managers, platform architects, and anyone interested in building scalable, secure and resilient CI/CD.

sessions.title: Supercharging Observability with Istio: A Deep Dive into Service Mesh Monitoring
sessions.description:
Service meshes like Istio are packed with impressive features, but did you know they can also revolutionize how you observe and monitor your applications—without requiring a ton of extra code? In this session, we’ll uncover how Istio brings observability to your stack, streamlining the way you track, diagnose, and solve issues in complex architectures.

We’ll kick things off by diving into Istio’s observability capabilities and explore how you can unlock deep insights into your applications' behavior with minimal effort.

Next, we’ll jump into the Kiali console UI, where we’ll showcase how Kiali’s intuitive visualizations give you a clear picture of your entire service mesh. You’ll learn how to spot issues instantly, understand service interactions, and detect bottlenecks—all at a glance.

But we won’t stop there! We’ll take a closer look at Jaeger’s distributed tracing capabilities, showing you how to trace service requests across the system and get to the root of any performance problems you’ve identified.

Lastly, we’ll harness the power of OpenTelemetry instrumentation to fill in any gaps that Istio’s native tools might miss, giving you a full-spectrum view of your application and helping you solve problems with precision.
This talk is perfect for developers and SREs looking to enhance their observability game using service mesh technologies. By the end of this session, you’ll have a solid understanding of Istio’s observability features, plus practical know-how to visualize, trace, and troubleshoot your services like a pro.

sessions.title: Supply Chain Security in action
sessions.description:
Want to know why in today's landscape of on-premises, cloud and edge technologies, Supply Chain Security is so important?

Want to know how to build and deploy secure applications using cutting-edge Open Source technology?

Join this session to learn more about SBOM, Tekton Chains, Sigstore and Secure Containers and watch a live demo of building and deploying secure applications and detecting a malicious attempt to hijack an application.

sessions.title: Systems Thinking for Vibe Coding
sessions.description: Vibe coding (programming with the help of AI) is making developers 3x more productive by reducing the toil and speeding up boilerplate code generation. The bottleneck of coding time is thus getting eliminated. But Systems thinking (and the Theory of Constraints) teaches us that we can only improve a process by elminiating the most limiting bottleneck in the chain of processes. Was coding ever that bottleneck? What other bottlenecks do we need to take care of now? Let's analyze software delivery in 2025 through the prism of Systems Thinking, define the challenges AI-assisted coding brings to the table and how to effectviely resolve them.

sessions.title: Talos in production
sessions.description: As a Cloud Native Engineer at TrueFullstaq we have a lot of experience running Talos in production. In this talk I'll feature some of the common pitfalls and patterns of using Kubernetes and Talos in all kinds of environments

sessions.title: Terraform, day 1001
sessions.description:
Have you ever seen a Terraform/OpenTofu tutorial from a perspective of full cloud migration running longer than 5 minutes? Most of them leave you after setting a VPC, VMs and some supplementary resources in the MVP state.

Then You are told to implement that technology in your complex production environment and ... there are enough 2nd day mistakes to conclude that IaaC sucks? Or maybe your company did click-ops till it becomes unmanageable, then fail to implement IaaC as an afterthought? 

Well, let me help you understand how to write code for scalable infrastructure that itself also scales. Without costly TACOS platforms that vendor lock you, just your favorite tools.

Let's fast track from typical Terraform Tutorial Repo to Enterprise Level Terraform with good practices gathered by someone who designed and fixed IaaC Architectures for companies ranging scale ups to big corporations!

sessions.title: The Absolute Beginner guide to cloud infrastructure : IaC(Infrastructure as code) 101
sessions.description:
New to the cloud native landscape? Feeling overwhelmed by the array of unfamiliar concepts and technologies? This session is designed to simplify the complexities of cloud native for you!

We'll break down the core concepts of cloud native – loosely coupled systems that are secure, resilient, manageable, sustainable, and observable – into easy-to-understand terms, using relatable analogies and real-world examples. We'll take you through the stages of the software development lifecycle, the basics of cloud infrastructure, and introduce you to Kubernetes.

By the end of this session, you'll have a clear understanding of the principles driving the cloud native movement and the practices that achieve its key characteristics.

Whether you're a complete beginner or simply looking for a way to explain your work to others, this session is for you!

sessions.title: The Cluster API Migration Retrospective: Live migrating hundreds of clusters to Cluster API
sessions.description:
Cluster API has become the industry standard for managing Kubernetes clusters, taking care of the heavy lifting of cluster operations.
However, migrating to Cluster API can still be challenging, especially for organisations heavily invested in existing cluster management tools.
This talk presents Giant Swarm's journey from a custom operator-based Kubernetes cluster management system to Cluster API, including the live migration of hundreds of production clusters of major enterprises such as adidas and Vodafone.
The driving force for the migration will be covered, followed by challenges encountered during the migration, concluding with a discussion of the observed benefits and differences seen post-migration.
Attendees will come away with an understanding of potential risks and challenges to be considered when migrating to Cluster API, a better insight into the expectations and efforts required, and the benefits of using this upstream project.

sessions.title: The Echidna Pattern: Scaling Platforms Without Losing Flexibility
sessions.description:
Imagine building a platform that starts small—clean, efficient, and focused. But as adoption grows, external teams begin knocking: “Can we integrate Feature X?” “How about supporting Protocol Y?” Each request feels urgent, and saying “no” isn’t an option. Before long, your core platform risks becoming a tangled mess of custom integrations, slowing development to a crawl.

This is where the Echidna architecture shines. Inspired by the spiny mammal’s adaptive defenses, the pattern encourages wrapping your core platform with modular “spikes”—lightweight APIs and hooks that act as controlled entry points. Instead of bending your platform to meet every external demand, you let stakeholders plug into these spikes. Need to support a new API standard? Add a spike. A third-party tool integration? Another spike. The core remains untouched, stable, and fast.

In this talk, we’ll walk through:

* The inflection point: When scaling demands force teams to choose between speed and flexibility
* Spikes in action: How APIs and hooks create safe, scalable interaction layers
* Real-world lessons: Balancing stakeholder needs without technical debt
* The payoff: Faster iterations, happier developers, and a platform that evolves with its ecosystem

By the end, you’ll see how Echidna turns integration chaos into a structured, sustainable strategy—keeping your platform nimble, no matter how many requests come knocking.

sessions.title: The end of SaaS as we know it
sessions.description:
As companies increasingly move to the cloud, they encounter common challenges such as security concerns, compliance requirements, raising costs, and operational complexity. This presentation explores how to deliver a SaaS experience on-premises using cloud-native tools to build a fully managed service on customers' infrastructure. We'll delve into leveraging tools like kcp, Kubernetes operators, Harbor, and more, along with new emerging tools.
The session will cover the technical intricacies, benefits, and challenges of three delivery models: fully managed (SaaS), hybrid (self-managed on rails), and packaged open source. We will offer practical insights and real-world examples throughout the discussion.

sessions.title: The Ethics of Containers: Is Cloud-Native Development Contributing to a Digital Divide?
sessions.description: As more organizations adopt containerized, cloud-native solutions, we’re moving away from traditional infrastructure models. But what are the socio-economic and ethical implications of this shift? Could containerization exacerbate the digital divide, concentrating power in the hands of a few cloud providers and global tech giants? This talk would explore the societal impact of containerization and cloud-native technologies.

sessions.title: The Future of Kubernetes Admission Logic
sessions.description:
Dynamic admission controllers have long played a pivotal role in enhancing the robustness and adaptability of clusters. For instance, ValidatingWebhookConfiguration empowers users to implement finely-tuned access controls beyond the capabilities of RBAC and MutatingWebhookConfiguration provides advanced defaulting logic for all resource. However, this often comes at a price – the ease with which they can be misconfigured, potentially leading to cluster disruption and downtime.

Historically, we’ve accepted this fragility as an inevitable trade-off for greater control over our clusters. But that ends now!

Enter CEL-based, in-process Admission Policies!

In this talk we’ll look at what makes ValidatingAdmissionPolicies and MutatingAdmissionPolicies a safer choice, we will dive into the features & limitations and draw comparisons with their webhook-based alternatives, highlighting problems they solve. Finally, we’ll walkthrough how you can leveraging them today and look at the future.

sessions.title: The Kubernetes server inside of Grafana
sessions.description:
Plugins are a vital part of the Grafana visualization software as they allow developers to build their own data sources, visualizations and even entire apps. Up until recently, there was one thing they couldn’t easily do: persist data. Solving this involves a lot of requirements: access policies, multitenancy, database access, cross-plugin extensibility and more. Our team started to draft out solutions which can handle all of these requirements and found their match in the Kubernetes API.

This talk covers the design and implementation details of embedding the Kubernetes API server inside of Grafana to allow for powerful extensibility through plugins. If you don’t have enough Kubernetes in your life, this talk is for you!

sessions.title: The Magic of Backing Service Provisioning and Consumption With Crossplane and ServiceBindings
sessions.description:
As the amount of cloud-native applications continues to rise, there is an unprecedented surge in the demand for backing services, amplifying the need for automated provisioning.

We will embark on a journey to demystify the complexity of managing and connecting backing services. 
Crossplane, a multi-cloud control plane, will take center stage as we explore its capabilities to automate the provisioning of backing services and expose simple, abstracted interfaces for developers to claim those.
The second component in this magical symphony are ServiceBindings that enable the automated supply of the required information for the connections between applications and their required backing services in a consistent way. 

This session is your compass to navigate the enchantment of effortless backing service provisioning and consumption and will illustrate how this dynamic duo enhances developer productivity, reduces operational overhead, and facilitates the seamless deployment of applications.

sessions.title: The OpenTelemetry Collector: What They Don’t Tell You!
sessions.description:
There’s a lot of buzz in the observability space about OpenTelemetry. After hearing about it for the 100th time, you’re finally convinced it’s time to adopt it—or maybe you’ve already started instrumenting your services. But now what?

You’ve got your services instrumented with OpenTelemetry, and you’re considering using an OpenTelemetry Collector. But do you really need one? How do you decide?

In this talk we will explore the OpenTelemetry Collector and cover:
- Whether you should use it—and when you might not need to.
- Its advantages and disadvantages.
- How to build your own distribution if you choose to use it.
- Common deployment patterns and best practices.

Join Juliano and Pablo in this talk to gain the insights and confidence you need to make informed decisions and take the next step in your observability journey!

sessions.title: The Service Mesh Wars: A New Hope for Kubernetes
sessions.description:
In a Kubernetes galaxy not so far away, operators face a crucial choice for managing and securing their networks: the simplicity of an Ingress controller or the power of a Service Mesh. Service Meshes promise resilient deployments with automatic retries, TLS encryption, traffic management, observability, and more. But not all meshes are created equal.

From Istio’s scalability, Linkerd’s simplicity, and Cilium’s eBPF innovation to Kuma’s multi-cluster versatility and Ambassador’s edge connectivity, each offers unique strengths. With options like sidecars or sidecar-less setups, choosing the right solution becomes a battle of priorities.

Join Henrik from Is It Observable? as he unveils a benchmark comparing these Service Mesh contenders across critical dimensions: proxy type, feature set, user experience, observability, and performance. By the end, you'll gain clarity on which Service Mesh aligns with your Kubernetes needs. May the Mesh be with you!

sessions.title: Think Big: Monitoring Stack was yesterday - Observability Platform at scale!
sessions.description:
In modern software engineering, monitoring your own systems is already a standardised and interchangeable commodity best purchased cheaply from experts. 

However, everyone has probably heard a joke at some point about how expensive these monitoring services can become once a system reaches a certain size. So would you rather build it yourself?

But as the complexity of your own systems increases, so does the effort of your monitoring stack - right up to the organisational question: Is monitoring just one component in every team or is it a separate product after all?

In this talk, we will therefore use the monitoring story of a B2B Kubernetes Cluster Fleet Management Platform (because why not a super complex system?) to explore how the commodity monitoring can be successfully organised across several teams and effectively deliver added value with product thinking and platform patterns, even to the end customer.

sessions.title: Tilt: local development setup for (micro)services
sessions.description: It's hard to re-create a complex setup with many services for local development environments. Tilt relieves the pain.

sessions.title: Training Reliable PyTorch Models on Cloud Spot Instances
sessions.description: This session will explore best practices for training PyTorch models on cloud spot instances while ensuring reliability and cost efficiency. I will cover strategies such as frequent checkpointing, handling instance interruptions, leveraging persistent storage, and using cloud-native tools like Kubernetes, AWS Batch, and Terraform for automated job orchestration. A hands-on demo will illustrate how to set up a resilient training pipeline using spot instances.

sessions.title: Transforming Clinical Drug Development with Cloud-Native Statistical Programming: Innovations, Chall
sessions.description:
Cloud-native statistical programming is revolutionizing clinical drug development, enabling pharmaceutical companies to analyze and manage clinical trial data with unprecedented scalability, speed, and precision. This talk delves into how cloud-native solutions accelerate clinical trials by addressing regulatory requirements, overcoming challenges, and driving innovation.

From Phase I to Phase IV, statistical programmers play a pivotal role in transforming protocols into programming specifications, automating derivations, and producing real-time safety and efficacy outputs. Cloud-native platforms enhance adaptive trial designs and interim analyses, streamlining decision-making and enabling faster, more accurate results. Innovations such as AI/ML algorithms now automate repetitive tasks, identify anomalies, and enhance predictive analytics, while scalable cloud infrastructure ensures seamless integration of complex datasets, including those from wearables and electronic health records (EHRs).

Compliance remains at the forefront, with cloud-native tools simplifying the generation of CDISC-compliant SDTM and ADaM datasets. Solutions like Pinnacle 21 validate datasets to ensure submission-readiness, while streamlined workflows expedite the creation of critical documents like Define.XML and cSDRG. Despite these advancements, challenges such as evolving regulatory expectations and the adoption of emerging tools like R and Python persist.

Through real-world case studies, this session will highlight the role of cloud-native platforms in accelerating clinical development while showcasing lessons learned from data-related delays. Attendees will explore actionable strategies for leveraging real-world evidence (RWE), decentralized clinical trial data, and open-source tools to modernize programming pipelines. By ensuring scalability, reproducibility, and traceability, cloud-native statistical programming is shaping the future of faster, compliant, and data-driven clinical innovation.

sessions.title: Using k9s for maximum efficiency
sessions.description: k9s is one of the best tools for quickly navigating and debugging any kubernetes cluster. But did you know you can extend it? Switch contexts, remove finalizers, parse JSON logs and even use an LLM to analyze what is going on with your applications

sessions.title: VMs in containers: What kind of sorcery is this?
sessions.description:
According to the CNCF Annual Survey 2023, only 39% replied that they use containers “for most or all production applications.” This indicates that many organizations have partially migrated their applications to containers or have not even started.

In the evolving cloud-native landscape, KubeVirt is a powerful tool bridging the gap between traditional virtualization and modern container orchestration. It addresses the requirement of running modern containerized applications along with traditional virtual machines by extending Kubernetes to manage VMs, enabling a unified platform for deploying and operating both types of applications.

In this session, we will explore the fundamental concepts and architecture of KubeVirt and how to manage VMs and containers side-by-side. The demo part will show how this can be achieved with the GitOps approach. We aim to equip you with the knowledge and practical skills to start with KubeVirt, whether you are a Kubernetes novice or an experienced user.

sessions.title: Wasm-Based Cloud Native LLM Agents and Plugins
sessions.description:
This talk dives into the integration of Large Language Models such as ChatGPT and open source LLMs with cloud-native ecosystems using WebAssembly (Wasm).

We’ll address the limitations of current LLM plugins and agents, often constrained by complex cloud infrastructure, and present Wasm as a lightweight, portable, and secure alternative. Our focus will be on how Wasm enhances LLM plugins, making them efficient and portable.

The session will showcase open-source community's efforts in building a Wasm container infra tailored for LLM plugins. Developers will see versatile solutions built on top of it with multi-LLMs like video translation tool etc.

Moreover, we'll look at the tech stack and the Rust SDKs developed by the community, underscoring their role in enabling these advanced LLM apps.

sessions.title: What agent to trust with your k8s: Falco, Tetragon or KubeAmor?
sessions.description:
In the CNCF landscape we have plenty of ebpf based security solutions that help us protect our k8s cluster from runtime vulnerabilities. On paper though Falco, Tetragon and KubeArmor look very similar. Eventually you have to make a choice on which one best fits your needs.
To give you additional insights to make your decision join this session. 
We have run extensive benchmarks against those three solutions and will answer the following questions that came out of our testing: 
-	What are the different featuresets?
-	 What about the performance impact of each agent? 
-	Which privileges does each solution need? 
-	What are the pros and cons across the three options?

sessions.title: What if...?
sessions.description:
Guiding principles in complexity.

How do we fuel creativity in organizations to, ultimately, increase innovation and improve business outcomes?

Through behaviour guided by the heuristics:
1. Be curious
2. Assume Complexity
3. Stay on Target

Main objective of the session is to challenge the audience to think about what behaviours fuel creativity and innovation. Especially the heuristics, or rules, that we utilize in our brain. Most often the application of these rules happen without us being aware, uncousciously or automatic.

For individuals it is immensely powerful to train yourself to be aware of your heuristics guiding your decision making and behaviour.

For leaders it is even more powerful to deliberatly design the environment for behaviours that are proven to improve creativity and innovation.

sessions.title: What the heck is Platform-as-a-Product?  - How product thinking drives your platform maturity
sessions.description:
The Cloud Native Computing Foundations (CNCF) Platform Engineering Maturity Model has made one thing pretty obvious: In order to have a mature (and successful) platform, you need to handle it as a product. But what does this even mean? If we rename the operations team to product team and stick a “product owner” title on some team member, now we’re done and more mature? 

Like with platforms in general, in product management, there is no real “one solution fits all”, and it strongly depends on your organizational context and individual preferences. There is, sadly, no checklist of tools and processes to simply adopt and be done; there is not even a Backstage for platform product management. There are, however, fundamental product thinking concepts and core values to provide direction and serve as your guide on this journey.

In this talk, we'll explore questions like: What is Platform-as-a-Product? How does product thinking in the platform space work and where can you start?

sessions.title: Who broke the build? — Using Kuttl to improve E2E testing and release faster
sessions.description:
No one wants to be responsible for breaking the build. But what can you do as a developer to avoid being the bad guy? How can project leads enable their teams to reduce the occurrence of broken builds?

In talking within our own teams, we discovered that many developers weren’t running sufficient integration and End to End tests in their local environments because it’s too difficult to set up and administer test environments in an efficient way.
That’s why we decided to rethink our entire local testing process in hopes of cutting down on the headaches, heartaches, and valuable time wasted. Enter Kuttl. Connecting Kuttl to CI builds has empowered our developers to easily configure a development environment locally that accurately matches the final test environment — without needing to become an expert CI admin themselves.

These days, we hear, “Who broke the build?” far less often — and you can too!

sessions.title: Works on my LLM: Building your own AI code assistant that isn't completely useless
sessions.description:
Tired of AI code assistants that don't quite adapt to you and your company? Welcome to the world of custom AI coding companions that actually get you and your code! This talk will give you all the open source ingredients to cook up an AI sidekick that understands your coding style and your company's internal developer tools and guidelines. 

Whether you're looking to boost personal productivity or enhance your team's workflow, you'll learn how to harness AI in a way that truly works for you - and might even make coding a bit more fun along the way.

sessions.title: Yes you can run LLMs on Kubernetes
sessions.description:
As LLMs become increasingly powerful and ubiquitous, the need to deploy and scale these models in production environments grows. However, the complexity of LLMs can make them challenging to run reliably and efficiently. In this talk, we'll explore how Kubernetes can be leveraged to run LLMs at scale.

We'll cover the key considerations and best practices for packaging LLM inference services as containerized applications using popular OSS inference servers like TGI, vLLM and Ollama, and deploying them on Kubernetes. This includes managing model weights, handling dynamic batching and scaling, implementing advanced traffic routing, and ensuring high availability and fault tolerance.

Additionally, we'll discuss accelerators management and serving models on multiple hosts. By the end of this talk, attendees will have a comprehensive understanding of how to successfully run their LLMs on Kubernetes, unlocking the benefits of scalability, resilience, and DevOps-friendly deployments.

sessions.title: You Ain't Gonna Need It (Yet): An Ode to Moduliths
sessions.description:
Your team debates microservices, Kubernetes clusters, and serverless—because everyone’s doing it. But what if the right choice is… none of them?
The “You Ain’t Gonna Need It” (YAGNI) principle isn’t about rejecting modern tools. It’s about rejecting guesses. Here’s the truth: Most projects evolve, and so should their architecture. Start simple. Scale deliberately.
In this talk, we’ll tackle:
Simplicity’s superpower: Why monoliths (or better: Moduliths!) still win for early-stage clarity
Evolutionary design: Letting requirements—not trends—dictate your tech stack
Complexity traps: Spotting overengineering red flags (e.g., “future-proofing” that never pays off)
When to pivot: Signals that it’s finally time to embrace those microservices
Real-world examples include a startup that scaled to 1M users on a “boring” monolith and an enterprise that saved $2M/year by deleting unused Kubernetes clusters. You’ll walk away with a filter for cutting through tech hype, aligning your architecture with today’s problems—and leaving tomorrow’s for tomorrow.

sessions.title: Zero Downtime, Maximum Play: Evolving Game Servers from Bare Metal to K3s
sessions.description: In this session, we’ll share our journey of transforming a high-performance, custom-protocol-based game server from a traditional bare-metal setup to a dynamic, Kubernetes-powered environment (k3s) hosted entirely by our team. This transition from a classic Java, database, and load balancer model to a fully containerized deployment leveraged powerful tools like ArgoCD, Helm, Istio, and the Prometheus stack to achieve zero downtime during updates (custom solution), boost server responsiveness, enhance player experience, and introduce agile deployment strategies including canary, blue-green, and autoscaling based on player session metrics. Attendees will gain insight into the specific architectural choices, the challenges of adapting custom communication protocols to cloud-native solutions, and how we balanced the demands of performance and flexibility—all while keeping players in mind.

speakers.bio: Aarno is a co-founder and was CTO for eight years at VSHN - The DevOps Company. Now working on 24x7 platform engineering in a pre-sales role.
speakers.tagLine: Partner at VSHN - The DevOps Company

speakers.bio: Abdel Sghiouar is a senior Cloud Developer Advocate @Google Cloud. A co-host of the Kubernetes Podcast by Google and a CNCF Ambassador. His focused areas are GKE/Kubernetes, Service Mesh and Serverless. Abdel started his career in datacenters and infrastructure in Morocco where he is originally. Before moving to Google's largest EU datacenter in Belgium. Then in Sweden he joined Google Cloud Professional Services and spent 5 years working with Google Cloud customers on architecting and designing large scale distributed systems before turning to advocacy and community work.

Abhilekh Verma is a founder, mentor and technical coach who has had a decade of experience in the IT industry working with Sales Teams and Corporate Training Roles. He was a corporate trainer at KPMG Gurugram and KPMG Hyderabad before jumping on the wagon of Entrepreneurship.
He is a mentor at Startupbootcamp, Wadhwani Foundation and runs Microsoft Azure Developer Community, ADP List, Omdena for Hyderabad. He is also a mentor at IIT Guwahati and Microsoft for Founders Hub. He is Microsoft MVP in AI.
speakers.tagLine: Director at Abhilekh Verma Consultancy (OPC) Private Limited

speakers.bio: Agile Tour Dublin, Various Tech Meetups, Trainer for 2 years at Tech Academy, Teaching Assistant for 1 year, Corporate Technical Trainer for 5 years(software architecture and development) (600 hours of training)
